For adults, the upper limit for total daily intake of thujone from health products is 6 mg. Product licence applications for oral products should include a copy of a certificate of analysis or any other equivalent document demonstrating that the thujone content of a daily dose of the product is acceptable. naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"84276";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:18:"Baptisia as an NHP under Schedule 1 item 1 (plant or plant material) of the NHP Regulations.";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:127:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 1 (plante ou matière végétale) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"84277";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:17:"Benincasa hispida";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"AHN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:5:"PLANT";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";s:5:"title";s:21:"Benincasa hispida_AHN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"196393";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:196394;a:25:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"93705";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:5212:"Mahonia aquifolium, a synonym for Berberis aquifolium, is a plant belonging to the family Berberidaceae, used in herbal and homeopathic medicines, orally for the management of gastrointestinal disorders; and topically, for skin disorders (Sweetman 2010, Tropicos 2010, USDA 2010).

Experimentally, this plant, its extracts and/or isolated constituents such as the alkaloids Aromoline, Baluchistine, Berbamine, Berberine, Jatrorrhizine, Magnoflorine, Oxycanthine and Palmatine, have shown antioxidant, free radical scavenging, antifungal, antibacterial, anti-inflammatory, antimutagenic, antiproliferative and vasodilating properties (Rackova et al. 2007, Rackova et al. 2004, Slobodnikova et al. 2004, Vollekova et al. 2003, Cernakova and Kostalova 2002, Hajnicka et al. 2002, Cernakova et al. 2002, Kostalova D. et al. 2001, Vollekova et al. 2001, Sotnikova et al. 1994).

Due to one or more of the above-mentioned properties, Mahonia aquifolium, its extracts and/or isolated constituents, have been clinically tested and proved somewhat safe and effective in the treatment of a variety of disorders, especially skin-related, such as psoriasis and dermatitis (Donsky and Clarke 2007, Bernstein et al. 2006, Gulliver and Donsky 2005).

As per the above information, Berberis aquifolium meets the substance aspect of the Natural Health Product (NHP) definition, under Schedule 1, item 1 (Plant) of the NHP Regulations (Government of Canada 2010).

Note that Mahonia aquifolium is already classified in the Natural Health Products Ingredients Database (NHPID) under the Approved Name 'Berberis aquifolium' (Health Canada 2010).

References:

    * Bernstein S., Donsky H., Gulliver W., Hamilton D., Nobel S., Norman R. 2006. Treatment of Mild to Moderate Psoriasis with Relieva, a Mahonia aquifolium Extract - a Double-Blind Placebo-Controlled Study. Americal Journal of Therapeutics 13: 121-126.
    * Cernakova M., Kostalova D., Kettmann V., Plodova M., Toth J., Drimal J. 2002. Potential Antimutagenic Activity of Berberine, a Constituent of Mahonia aquifolium. BMC Complementary and Alternative Medicine 2: 2.
    * Cernokova M., Kostalova D. 2002. Antimicrobial Activity of Berberine - a Constituent of Mahonia aquifolium. Folia Microbiol. 47(4): 375-378.
    * Donsky H., Clarke D. 2007. Relieva, a Mahonia aquifolium Extract for the Treatment of Adult Patients with Atopic Dermatitis. Americal Journal of Therapeutics 14: 442-446.

    * Hajnicka V., Kostalova D., Svecova D., Sochorova R., Fuchsberger N., Toth J. 2002. Effect of Mahonia aquifolium Active Compounds on Interleukin-8 Production in the Human Monocytic Cell Line THP-1. Planta Med. 68: 266-268.

10:36 AM    Butea superba is a Thai plant that has been used traditionally to increase sexual vigor. The raw extract from the root of Red Kwao Krua contains flavonoids and flavonoid glycosides demonstrating comparable benefit as that of the pill Viagra (TM). Red Kwao Krua is already marketed in the Far East, Japan, Europe and recently USA. Les substances présentes à cette Annexe sont excluses de la Loi sur les produits de santé naturels; et conséquemment, les drogues obtenues par des procédures de recombinaison de l'ADN, incluant les Référence: http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/cps-spc/person/cosmet/info-ind-prof/_hot-list-critique/prohibited-fra.php";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"84384";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:16:"Conium maculatum";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"AHN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:5:"PLANT";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:3:"CIH";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";s:5:"title";s:20:"Conium maculatum_AHN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"196497";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:196498;a:24:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:1948:"2006-06-12  03:53 PM    Lily of the Valley is the sole member of the genus Convallaria in the flowering plant family Ruscaceae. It is native throughout the cool temperate Northern Hemisphere in Asia, Europe and North America. The applicable parts of lily of the valley are the root, rhizome, and dried flowering tops. Lily of the valley contains over 40 cardioactive glycosides, principally convallatoxin; and other minor glycosides, including canvallatoxol and convalloside.  These glycosides have been used in medicine for centuries. In overdose preparations can be poisonous (especially when the standardized extract is used orally for self-medication). Children and pets can be harmed by eating Lily of the Valley. Lily of the valley has a short duration of action. This correlates with lower absorption rates and makes treatment more difficult to control than with isolated cardiac glycosides, especially due to the narrow therapeutic range of these constituents. When indicated, digoxin of standard potency and purity is a safer alternative than nonstandardized lily of the valley. It is on the "List of herbs unacceptable as non-medicinal ingredients in oral use products". However, 'Natural Medicines Comprehensive Database' considers it as 'possibly safe' when the standardized extract is used orally under medical supervision [the average daily amount is 600 mg of the standardized lily of the valley powder (0.2-0.3% cardioactive glycosides) or equivalent preparations]. Lily of the Valley will be considered as an NHP under plant, item 1, schedule 1 of the NHP Regulations.     Please note that because of the risk associated with the ingestion of Lily of the Valley that have over 40 cardioactive glycosides as well saponine, and the fact that poisoning and death in humans after accidental ingestion of the berries and leaves, and even by drinking the water that the plants were kept in, this plant may not be appropriate as OTC Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:736:"Not applicable to whole herb preparations: The quantity or concentration of carvacrol in all applicable essential oils or extracts must be declared. Based on safety concerns, thyme essential oil oral intake of up to 4.16 micrograms/kg body weight per day is allowed, and the daily oral exposure of carvacrol from the product must not exceed 0.23 micrograms/kg bw per day. If applicants would like to use a thyme essential oil or extract with a higher content of carvacrol as a non-medicinal ingredient (NMI) in their product, they must provide evidence to support its safe use. In the absence of adequate safety evidence, if the daily exposure of carvacrol exceeds the specified maximum, the ingredient cannot be considered to be a NMI.";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:958:"Non applicable au préparations à base de plantes complètes: La quantité ou concentration de carvacrol dans toutes les huiles ou extraits essentiels applicables doit être déclarée. À cause de préoccupations reliées à l'innocuité, un apport orale d'huile de thyme allant jusqu'à 0.27 microgrammes/kg de poids corporel par jour est permis, et l’exposition orale quotidienne au carvacrol provenant du produit ne doit pas dépasser 0.23 microgrammes/kg de poids corporel par jour. Si les demandeurs veulent utiliser une huile essentielle ou extrait de thym qui contient une quantité élevée de carvacrol comme ingrédient non-médicinal dans leur produit, ils doivent fournir des preuves pour supporter son usage sécuritaire. Dans l’absence de preuves suffisantes appuyant l’innocuité, si l’exposition au carvacrol dépasse la valeur maximale spécifiée, l’ingrédient ne peut pas être considéré comme un ingrédient naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"84398";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:14:"Crocus sativus";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"AHN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:5:"PLANT";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";s:5:"title";s:18:"Crocus sativus_AHN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"196511";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:196512;a:24:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:1070:"2006-07-30  03:54 PM    Croton lechleri (Sangre de drago; Spanish for "blood of the dragon" because of its thick red sap), is a medium-sized tree that grows throughout the South Ameria. The blood-red latex or sap (and also its bark) is used as a common household remedy in most latin american countries and people. Sangre de grado resin is a storehouse of plant chemicals including proanthocyanidins (antioxidants), simple phenols, diterpenes, phytosterols, and biologically active alkaloids and lignans. Scientists have attributed many of the biologically active properties of the resin to two main "active" constituents: an alkaloid named tapsine, and a lignan named dimethylcedrusine.   The best known member of the croton genus is probably Croton tiglium. Croton oil, used in herbal medicine as a violent purgative, is extracted from its seeds. Nowadays, it is considered unsafe and it is no longer listed in the pharmacopeias of many countries (including Canada).   However, Croton lechleri will be considered as a NHP, under schedule 1, item 1, Priority 4 (plant).";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:94:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1 item 1 (plant or plant material) of the NHP Regulations.";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:127:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 1 (plante ou matière végétale) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"84399";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:15:"Croton lechleri";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"AHN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:5:"PLANT";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";s:5:"title";s:19:"Croton lechleri_AHN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"196512";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:196513;a:25:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:17:"92722;93355;92722";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:0:"";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:459:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1 item 1 (plant or plant material) of the NHP Regulations. This ingredient  is on the Restricted Substances list in the Natural Health Products Compliance Guide. Unauthorized products with this ingredient are subject to the risk-based approach to compliance. A product licence must be obtained prior to marketing in Canada . Reference:http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/dhp-mps/prodnatur/legislation/docs/complian-conform_guide-eng.php";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:674:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 1 (plante ou matière végétale) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels.  Cet ingrédient apparaît sur la liste des substances prohibées du Guide de conformité concernant les produits de santé naturels. Les produits contenant cet ingrédient qui n'ont pas d'autorisation de mise en marché sont sujets à une approche de conformité qui est prise conjointement avec une approche basée sur les risques. Une licence de mise en marché doit être obtenue avec de pouvoir poursuivre la commercialisation du produit. Cynomorium grows at high altitude, mainly in Inner Mongolia and Tibet. In Saudi Arabia, cynomorium is called tarthuth. It even grows in parts of the Sahara desert. Reference: http://publications.gc.ca/collections/Collection/H164-29-2006E.pdf";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:655:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 1 (plante ou matière végétale) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels.  Cet ingrédient apparaît sur la liste des substances prohibées du Guide de conformité concernant les produits de santé naturels.  Les produits contenant cet ingrédient qui n'ont pas d'autorisation de mise en marché sont sujets à une approche de conformité qui est prise conjointement avec une approche basée sur les risques.  Une licence de mise en marché doit être obtenue avec de pouvoir poursuivre la commercialisation du produit. naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"84481";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:13:"Euryale ferox";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"AHN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:5:"PLANT";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";s:5:"title";s:17:"Euryale ferox_AHN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"196591";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:196592;a:24:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:0:"";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:94:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1 item 1 (plant or plant material) of the NHP Regulations.";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:127:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 1 (plante ou matière végétale) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"84482";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:19:"Eurycoma longifolia";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"AHN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:5:"PLANT";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";s:5:"title";s:23:"Eurycoma longifolia_AHN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"196592";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:196593;a:24:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:0:"";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:94:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1 item 1 (plant or plant material) of the NHP Regulations.";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:127:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 1 (plante ou matière végétale) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"84483";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:20:"Fagopyrum esculentum";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"AHN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:5:"PLANT";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";s:5:"title";s:24:"Fagopyrum esculentum_AHN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"196593";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:196594;a:25:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"92860";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:7583:"Bioactive compounds isolated from this plant are, for the most part, anthraquinones such as emodin and citreorosein (Zhang et al. 2009, Zhuang et al. 2008, Jayasuriya et al. 1992), stilbenes such as resveratrol, piceid, and polydatin (Fan et al. 2009, Wang et al. 2008, Benova et al. 2008, Xiao et al. 2000, Vastano et al. 2000, Jayatilake et al. 1993), as well as other phenolics (Hegde et al. 2004, Xiao et al. 2002). Pharmacokinetics, in terms of tissue distribution and excretion, have also been studied in rats, based on one of the major constituent found in Polygonum cuspidatum extract, namely resveratrol (Wang et al. 2008).

Experimentally, Polygonum cuspidatum, its extracts (mainly root) and/or active principles, has shown to possess antibacterial (Ban et al. 2009, Song et al. 2007, Song et al. 2006), antitumor and antimetastatic (Kimura and Okuda 2001), anti-inflammatory (Bralley et al. 2008, Kim et al. 2007), estrogenic (Zhang et al. 2006, Liu et al. 2005, Matsuda et al. 2001), lipid-lowering (Du et al. 2009, Xing et al. 2009, Park et al. 2004), anti-hepatitis (Chang et al. 2005), as well as skin-whitening (Leu et al. 2008) effects.

Based on the above information, Polygonum cuspidatum meets the substance aspect of the natural health product (NHP) definition, as outlined in the NHP Regulations (Justice Canada 2009).

References:

Ban S.-H., Kwon Y.-R., Pandit S., Lee Y.-S., Yi H.-K., Jeon J.-G. 2009. Effects of a bio-assay guided fraction from Polygonum cuspidatum root on the viability, acid production and glucosyltransferase of mutans streptococci. Fitoterapia doi: 10.1016/j.fitote.2009.06.019. 
Benova B., Adam M., Onderkova K., Kralovsky J., Krajicek M. 2008. Analysis of selected stilbenes in Polygonum cuspidatum by HPLC coupled with CoulArray detection. J. Sep. Sci. 31: 2404-2409. 
Bralley E.E., Greenspan P., Hargrove J.L., Wicker L., Hartle D.K. 2008. Topical anti-inflammatory activity of Polygonum cuspidatum extract in the TPA model of mouse ear inflammation. Journal of Inflammation 5: 1. 
Chang J.-S., Liu H.-W., Wang K.-C., Chen M.-C., Chiang L.-C., Hua Y.-C., Lin C.-C. 2005. Ethanol extract of Polygonum cuspidatum inhibits hepatitis B virus in a stable HBV-producing cell line. Antiviral Research 66: 29-34. 
Du J., Sun L.-N., Xing W.-W., Huang B.-K., Jia M., Wu J.-Z., Zhang H., Qin L.-P. 2009. Lipid-lowering effect of polydatin from Polygonum cuspidatum in hyperlipidemic hamsters. Phytomedicine 16: 652-658. 
Fan P., Marston A., Hay A.-E., Hostettmann K. 2009. Rapid separation of three glucosylated resveratrol analogues from the invasive plant Polygonum cuspidatum by high-speed countercurrent chromatography. J. Sep. Sci. 32: 2979-2984.

Jayasuriya H., Koonchanok N.M., Geahlen R.L., McLaughlin J.L., Chang C.-J. 1992. Emodin, a protein tyrosine kinase inhibitor from Polygonum cuspidatum. Journal of Natural Products 55(5): 696-698. 
Jayatilake G.S., Jayasuriya H., Lee E.-S., Koonchanok N.M., Gaehlen R.L., Ashendel C.L., McLaughlin J.L., Chang C.-J. 1993. Kinase Inhibitors from Polygonum cuspidatum. Journal of Natural Products 56(10): 1805-1810. 
Justice Canada 2009. Natural Health Products Regulations. URL: http://laws.justice.gc.ca/en/showtdm/cr/SOR-2003-196//?showtoc=&instrumentnumber=SOR-2003-196 [Accessed 2009-10-29]. 
Kim K.-W., Ha K.-T., Park C.-S., Jin U.-H., Chang H.W., Lee I.-S., Kim C.-H. 2007. Polygonum cuspidatum, compared with baicalin and berberine, inhibits inducible nitric oxide synthase and cyclooxygenase-2 gene expressions in RAW 264.7 macrophages. Vascular Pharmacology 47: 99-107. 
Kimura Y., Okuda H. 2001. Resveratrol Isolated from Polygonum cuspidatum Root Prevetns Tumor Growth and Metastasis to Lung and Tumor-Induced Neovascularization in Lewis Lung Carcinoma-Bearing Mice. J. Nutr. 131: 1844-1849. 
Leu Y.-L., Hwang T.-L., Hu J.-W., Fang J.-Y. 2008. Anthraquinones from Polygonum cuspidatum as Tyrosinase Inhibitors for Dermal Use. Phytotherapy Research 22: 552-556. 
Liu Z.P., Li W.X., Yu B., Huang J., Sun J., Huo J.S., Liu C.X. 2005. Effects of trans-Resveratrol from Polygonum cuspidatum on Bone Loss Using the Ovariectomized Rat Model. J. Med. Food 8(1): 14-19. 
Matsuda H., Shimoda S., Morikawa T., Yoshikawa M. 2001. Phytoestrogens from the Roots of Polygonum cuspidatum (Polygonaceae): Structure-Requirement of Hydroxyanthraquinones for Estrogenic Activity. Bioorganic & Medicinal Chemistry Letters 11: 1839-1842. 
Park C.-S., Lee Y.-C., Kim J.-D., Kim H.-M., Kim C.-H. 2004. Inhibitory effects of Polygonum cuspidatum water extract (PCWE) and its component resveratrol on acyl-coenzyme A-cholesterol acyltransferase activity for cholesteryl ester synthesis in HepG2 cells. Vascular Pharmacology 40: 279-284. 
Song J.-H., Kim S.-K., Chang K.-W., Han S.-K., Yi H.-K., Jeon J.-G. 2006. In vitro inhibitory effects of Polygonum cuspidatum on bacterial viability and virulence factors of Streptococcus mutans and Streptococcus sobrinus. Archives of Oral Biology 51: 1131-1140. 
Song J.-H., Yang T.-C., Chang K.-W., Han S.-K., Yi H.-K., Jeon J.-G. 2007. In vitro effects of a fraction separated from Polygonum cuspidatum root on the viability, in suspension and biofilms, and biofilm formation of mutans streptococci. Journal of Ethnopharmacology 112: 419-425.

Wang D., Xu Y., Liu W. 2008. Tissue distribution and excretion of resveratrol in rat after oral administration of Polygonum cuspidatum extract. Phytomedicine 15: 859-866.

Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"84599";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:19:"Lophatherum gracile";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"AHN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:5:"PLANT";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";s:5:"title";s:23:"Lophatherum gracile_AHN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"196708";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:196709;a:24:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:1777:"06/30/2006  11:39 AM    Peyote (Lophophora williamsii) is a small spineless cactus, originating from the southwestern USA to central Mexico.  All Lophophora plants are known to be very slow growing plants, taking up to 30 years to reach flowering age in the wild and little faster when grown by Humans, up to 6 to 10 years to go from seedling to mature flowering adult.  Because of its slow growth and over-harvesting, Peyote itself is considered to be in danger of extinction in the wild.  Peyote contains large amount of phenethylamine alkaloids, mainly Mescaline, which is well known for its hallucinogen properties, just like another well known drug LSD.  It is important to notice that the principal alkaloid of Peyote, Mescaline and any of its salts, is considered as a Controlled drug, since it is listed in Schedule III of the Controlled Drugs and Substances Act as follows:     17. Mescaline (3,4,5--trimethoxybenzeneethanamine) and any salt thereof, but not Peyote (lophophora)    Peyote is illegal in several countries because of its content in Mescaline; however, under special religious conditions, these laws protects the harvest, possession and consumption (usually not cultivation) for some religious groups, such as "Native Americans", which use Peyote as a "Traditional Indian religious sacrament".  Medicinally, the above ground parts of Peyote are used orally for treating fevers, rheumatism, and paralysis; and also topically for treating fractures, wounds, and snake bites.  Even though it contains a Mescaline ( a Controlled Drug substance), Peyote is excluded from Schedule III of the Controlled Drugs and Substances Act (see above) and will be considered as an NHP, under Schedule 1, item 1 (Priority 4; Plant or Plant material) of the NHP Regulations.";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:94:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1 item officinalis";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"AHN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:5:"PLANT";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";s:5:"title";s:23:"Morinda officinalis_AHN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"196748";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:196749;a:24:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:1433:"2006-07-22  03:06 PM    Moringa oleifera is the most cultivated variety of the genus Moringa, which is why this specific species is more commonly known as Moringa.  This semi-arid tropical and subtropical tree is considered as one of the most useful tree in the world, as most part of this tree can be used as food and for other properties, since the bark, sap, roots, leaves, seeds, oil and flowers are used in traditional medicine in several countries.  It is important to notice that according to Wikipedia, the root of this tree, which are shredded and used as a condiment, contains the alkaloid Spirochin, which is known to be a fatal nerve paralyzing agent.  Also, two published articles found in Pubmed have shown that the alcohol/water leaf and root extracts of Moringa oleifera had demonstrated some antifertility effect, possibly due to multiple attributes.  For example, the leaf extract of Moringa oleifera had shown to be 100% abortive at doses to 175mg/Kg of starting dry material; however, it is also important to notice that no data on humans consumption was found.  Despite the fact that some published articles showed potential severe safety issues (which may be assessed further by safety & efficacy assessment officers), Moringa oleifera is a naturally occurring tree; therefore it meets the definition of a NHP, and will be considered as such, under Schedule 1, item 1 (Priority 4; Plant) of the NHP Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:608:"The quantity or concentration of carvacrol in all applicable essential oils or extracts must be declared. Not applicable to whole herb preparations: Based on safety concerns, oregano oil intake of up to 0.27 micrograms/kg body weight per day is allowed. Applicants must provide evidence to support the safe use of the carvacrol content of oil of oregano, if they would like to use a higher quantity as a NMI in their product. If the daily exposure of carvacrol exceeds 0.23 micrograms/kg bw per day from the NHP in the absence of adequate safety evidence, the oil of oregano cannot be considered to be a NMI.";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:811:"La quantité ou concentration de carvacrol dans toutes les huiles ou extraits essentiels applicables doit être déclarée
Non applicable au préparations à base de plantes complètes: À cause de préoccupations reliées à l'innocuité, un apport d'huile d'origan allant jusqu'à 0.27 microgrammes/kg de poids corporel par jour est permis. Les demandeurs doivent fournir des preuves appuyant l'innocuité de la quantité du carvacrol présente dans l'huile d'origan s'ils désirent en utiliser une quantité plus élevée comme ingrédient non médicinal dans leurs produits. En l'absence de donnés appuyant l'innocuité, l'huile d'origan ne peut pas être considérée comme ingrédient non médicinal si l'exposition du carvacrol provenant du PSN dépasse 0.23 microgrammes /kg de poids corporel par jour.";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"84665";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:17:"Origanum majorana";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"AHN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:5:"PLANT";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";s:5:"title";s:21:"Origanum majorana_AHN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"196774";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:196775;a:25:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:13:"101130;103663";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:0:"";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:94:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1 item 1 (plant or plant material) of the NHP Regulations.";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:127:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 1 (plante ou matière végétale) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:609:"The quantity or concentration of carvacrol in all applicable essential oils or extracts must be declared. 
Not applicable to whole herb preparations: Based on safety concerns, oregano oil intake of up to 0.27 micrograms/kg body weight per day is allowed. Applicants must provide evidence to support the safe use of the carvacrol content of oil of oregano, if they would like to use a higher quantity as a NMI in their product. If the daily exposure of carvacrol exceeds 0.23 micrograms/kg bw per day from the NHP in the absence of adequate safety evidence, the oil of oregano cannot be considered to be a NMI.";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:811:"La quantité ou concentration de carvacrol dans toutes les huiles ou extraits essentiels applicables doit être déclarée
Non applicable au préparations à base de plantes complètes: À cause de préoccupations reliées à l'innocuité, un apport d'huile d'origan allant jusqu'à 0.27 microgrammes/kg de poids corporel par jour est permis. Les demandeurs doivent fournir des preuves appuyant l'innocuité de la quantité du carvacrol présente dans l'huile d'origan s'ils désirent en utiliser une quantité plus élevée comme ingrédient non médicinal dans leurs produits. En l'absence de donnés appuyant l'innocuité, l'huile d'origan ne peut pas être considérée comme ingrédient non médicinal si l'exposition du carvacrol provenant du PSN dépasse 0.23 microgrammes /kg de oyster mushroom is one of nearly 40 edible species of the genus Pleurotus.  
It is wide-spread in temperate forests throughout the world. It grows on dead wood year round and all strains need moist conditions to fruit although different strains fruit in different temperature ranges.  Oyster mushrooms are a source of statin drugs. This mushroom is also one of the few known carnivorous mushrooms. Oyster mushroom will be considered as a NHP, under Schedule 1, item 1, Priority 3 (Fungus).";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:77:"Classified as an NHP under as an NHP under Schedule 1 item 1 (plant or plant material) of the NHP Regulations.";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:127:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 1 (plante ou matière végétale) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"84785";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:10:"Salix alba";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"AHN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:5:"PLANT";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";s:5:"title";s:14:"Salix alba_AHN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"196889";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:196890;a:24:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:1382:"2006-05-31  04:25 PM    Miswak (miswaak, siwak) is a natural tooth brush used in the Muslim culture since before the days of Islam's inception. A miswak is typically made from the twigs of the Salvadora persica tree growing in the Middle East. Other tree types that are used are the arak tree, peelo tree, olive, walnut and other trees with bitter roots. Pomegranate is never used for miswak.  In addition to strengthening the gums, preventing tooth decay and eliminating toothaches it is also said to halt further increase in decay that has already set in. Furthermore it is claimed to create a fragrance in the mouth, eliminate bad odour, improve the sense of taste and cause the teeth to glow.  Benefits not related to teeth and gum include sharpening memory, curing headaches, creating a lustre on the face of the one who continually uses it, strengthening the eyesight, assisting in digestion and clearing the voice.  The WHO recommended the use of the miswak in 1986 and in 2000 an international concensus report on oral hygiene concluded that further research was needed to document the effect of the miswak.  Miswak owe its properties to its high content of various beneficial compounds, such as tannins, alkaloids, vitamin C, minerals and aromatic substances. Miswak will be considered as a NHP, under Schedule 1, item 1 (Priority 4; Plant material) of the NHP Regulations.";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:94:"Classified 02:12 PM    Sida Cordifolia has been used in India for over 2,000 years to treat bronchial asthma cold & flu, chills, lack of perspiration, headache, nasal congestion, aching joints and bones, cough & wheezing, and edema. In Western terms, Sida Cordifolia is considered to have diaphoretic, diuretic, central nervous system stimulating and anti-asthmatic properties. cumini is a Syzygium species (an evergreen tropical tree) from family myrtaceae (IOPI 2007; NCBI 2009) native to Bangladesh, India, Nepal, Pakistan, Indonesia and also grows in Florida, Oceania, and south America (KI/GCI/APNI 2004; ITIS 2009). It contains many chemicals including anthocyanins, tannins, phenols, beta-sitosterol, quercetin, eugenin, etc. (Khare 2007). Several actions for Syzygium cumini have been found; stomachic, carminative, diuretic (fruit), antidiarrhoeal (bark and seed), hypoglycaemic (seed), and antibacterial, antidysenteric (leaf) (Duke 2002). Syzygium cumini will be considered as a NHP, under schedule 1, item 1, Priority 4 (plants).

Comfrey as been used orally as a tea in the treatment of gastritis, ulcers, excessive menstrual flow, diarrhea, bloody urine, persistent cough, pleuritis, bronchitis, cancer, angina and pharyngitis.  Topically, this herb has been used for ulcers, wounds, joint inflammation, bruises, rheumatoid arthritis, phlebitis, gout and fractures. Therefore, common comfrey (Symphytum officinale) will be considered as a NHP, under Schedule 1, item 1 (Priority 4; Plant) of the NHP Regulations. However, other comfrey species, namely Symphytum asperum and  Symphytum x uplandicum, will not be considered as NHPs because they contain Echimidine. Echimidine, its salts and any of the plant species or extracts or tinctures containing Echimidine are included under the prohibited substances list in the Food and Drugs Les détails sont disponibles de cette(ces) référence(s). http://www.sararegistry.gc.ca/species/speciesDetails_e.cfm?sid=820";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"84848";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:20:"Syntrichia laevipila";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"AHN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:5:"PLANT";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";s:5:"title";s:24:"Syntrichia laevipila_AHN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"196949";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:196950;a:25:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"93690";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:1238:"Syzygium cumini is a Syzygium species (an evergreen tropical tree) from family myrtaceae (IOPI 2007; NCBI 2009) native to Bangladesh, India, Nepal, Pakistan, Indonesia and also grows in Florida, Oceania, and south America (KI/GCI/APNI 2004; ITIS 2009). It contains many chemicals including anthocyanins, tannins, phenols, beta-sitosterol, quercetin, eugenin, etc. (Khare 2007). Several actions for Syzygium cumini have been found; stomachic, carminative, diuretic (fruit), antidiarrhoeal (bark and seed), hypoglycaemic (seed), and antibacterial, antidysenteric (leaf) (Duke 2002). Syzygium cumini will be considered as a NHP, under schedule 1, item 1, Priority 4 (plants).

 03:54 PM    Felty germander (Teucrium polium), a flowering plant native to the Mediterranean region and Middle East, is used in cooking and for medicinal purposes, such as in the treatment of stomach disorders, since it has demonstrated some effectiveness in relieving visceral pain in mice.  It is important to notice that this species of germander, along with other germander species, have caused acute hepatitis when consumed for 1 month in relatively high doses.  Despite these safety issues, Felty germander still meets the definition of a NHP; therefore it will be considered as such under Schedule 1, item 1 (Priority 4; Plant) of the NHP Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:736:"Not applicable to whole herb preparations: The quantity or concentration of carvacrol in all applicable essential oils or extracts must be declared. Based on safety concerns, thyme essential oil oral intake of up to 4.16 micrograms/kg body weight per day is allowed, and the daily oral exposure of carvacrol from the product must not exceed 0.23 micrograms/kg bw per day. If applicants would like to use a thyme essential oil or extract with a higher content of carvacrol as a non-medicinal ingredient (NMI) in their product, they must provide evidence to support its safe use. In the absence of adequate safety evidence, if the daily exposure of carvacrol exceeds the specified maximum, the ingredient cannot be considered to be a NMI.";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:958:"Non applicable au préparations à base de plantes complètes: La quantité ou concentration de carvacrol dans toutes les huiles ou extraits essentiels applicables doit être déclarée. À cause de préoccupations reliées à l'innocuité, un apport orale d'huile de thyme allant jusqu'à 0.27 microgrammes/kg de poids corporel par jour est permis, et l’exposition orale quotidienne au carvacrol provenant du produit ne doit pas dépasser 0.23 microgrammes/kg de poids corporel par jour. Si les demandeurs veulent utiliser une huile essentielle ou extrait de thym qui contient une quantité élevée de carvacrol comme ingrédient non-médicinal dans leur produit, ils doivent fournir des preuves pour supporter son usage sécuritaire. Dans l’absence de preuves suffisantes appuyant l’innocuité, si l’exposition au carvacrol dépasse la valeur maximale spécifiée, l’ingrédient ne peut pas être considéré comme un ingrédient Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"84895";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:24:"Veronicastrum virginicum";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"AHN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:5:"PLANT";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";s:5:"title";s:28:"Veronicastrum virginicum_AHN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"196995";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:196996;a:25:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"93705";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:2079:"Viburnum opulus, commonly known as Guelder-rose or Crampbark, is a plant belonging to the family Adoxaceae  (USDA 2010).

Other than its antispasmodic activity, Viburnum opulus, its extracts and/or active constituents such as proanthocyanidins, have shown antioxidant properties (O'Neil et al. 2009, Altun et al. 2008, Zayachkivska et al. 2006).

As per the information outlined above, Viburnum opulus meets the substance aspect of the Natural Health Product (NHP) definition, under Schedule 1, item 1 (Plant) of the NHP Regulations (Government of Canada 2010).

Note that Viburnum opulus is already classified in the Natural Health Products Ingredients Database (NHPID; Health Canada 2010).

References:

    * Altun M.L., Citoglu G.S., Yilmaz B.S., Coban T. 2008. Antioxidant Properties of Viburnum opulus and Viburnum lantana Growing in Turkey. International Journal of Food Sciences and Nutrition 59(3): 175-180.
    * Government of Canada 2010. Natural Health Products Regulations. URL: http://laws.justice.gc.ca/en/showtdm/cr/SOR-2003-196//?showtoc=&instrumentnumber=SOR-2003-196 [Accessed 2010-01-20].
    * Health Canada 2010. Natural Health Products Ingredients Database. URL: http://webprod.hc-sc.gc.ca/nhpid-bdipsn/search-rechercheReq.do [Accessed 2010-01-19].
    * O’Neil M.J., Heckelman P.E., Koch C.B., Roman K.J. (Eds). 2009. The Merck Index: an encyclopedia of chemicals, drugs, and Biologicals, Fourteenth Edition (2006). Merck & Co. Inc., Whitehouse Station, NJ, USA. Electronic version [Accessed 210-01-20].

moss is a species of red algae, Chondrus crispus, which grows along the rocky parts of Atlantic coast of Europe and North America.  It is a major source of Carrageenan (or Irish moss extract) (present in the NHPD acceptable NMIs list), which is commonly used as a thickener and stabilizer in processed foods.  The properties of this herb are alterative, anti-inflammatory, demulcent, emollient, expectorant, immune stimulant and laxative. There is now agreement that they are distinct genera, and that the food species belong to Arthrospira; nonetheless, the inaccurate term "Spirulina" remains the popular name. There are conflicting opinions about whether A. oryzae can be isolated in nature. Although the details of the genetic relationship between A. oryzae and A. flavus remain unclear, the two species are so closely related that all strains of A. oryzae are regarded by some as natural variants of A. flavus modified through years of selection for fermenting of foods. A. oryzae is regarded as not being pathogenic for plants or animals, though there are a handful of reports of isolation of A. oryzae from patients. There are also several reports of products of A. oryzae fermentations, e.g. a-amylase, that seem to be associated with allergic responses in certain occupations with high exposure to those materials. A. oryzae can produce a variety of mycotoxins when fermentation is extended beyond the usual time needed for production of these foods. While wild A. flavus isolates readily produce aflatoxins and other mycotoxins, A. oryzae has not been shown to be capable of aflatoxin production.";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:77:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1 item 1 (fungus) of the NHP Regulations.";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:108:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 1 (champignon) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"84948";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:30:"Aspergillus flavus var. oryzae";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"AHN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:4:"FUNG";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";s:5:"title";s:34:"Aspergillus flavus var. oryzae_AHN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"197047";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:197048;a:25:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"94423";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:364:"The Birch bracket (Piptoporus betulinus) is one of the most common polyporous bracket fungi that grows almost exclusively on Birch trees, which is why this mushroom was named Birch bracket. This ingredient (both as an extract or as the fruit body) is known for its ability to stimulate synthesis of Nerve Growth Factor (NGF), which plays a role in many neurological disorders, such as Alzheimer’s disease, as well as being used for the treatment of different digestive tract problems, such as ulcers.  For these reasons, Lion’s mane mushroom will be considered as a NHP, under Schedule 1, item 1 (Priority 3; Fungus) of the NHP Regulations.The bearded tooth fungus is also known as the tree hedgehog fungus. It belongs to the family of tooth fungi, which are rare in Britain, and associated with old trees. This species gets its popular name from its appearance, which does resemble a white hedgehog. is a common term that may be referencing any of various coniferous trees and shrubs in the genus Taxus, but more commonly for the common yew Taxus baccata; therefore, this classification will be for this specific species only.   Taxus baccata is a conifer tree native to western, central and southern Europe, northwest Africa, northern Iran and southwest Asia.  This specific species of conifer was originally (and still) known in English as just Yew; however, the later discovery of related species as led to a more concise qualification, namely Common Yew, European Yew or English Yew.  Orally, Yew has been used for promoting menstruation, inducing abortion, treating diphtheria, tapeworm infestation, tonsillitis, epilepsy, rheumatism, urinary tract conditions and liver conditions.  However, all parts of yew plant are considered poisonous except the bright red aril surrounding the seed,  demonstrating by the fact that ingestion of 50-100 grams of yew needles have caused death in the past.  Despite the fact that yew is considered highly toxic, it is a naturally occurring plant not captured in Schedule F and/or any others, it will be considered as a NHP, under Schedule 1, item 1 (Priority 4; Plant) of the NHP Regulations";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:94:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1 item 1 (plant or plant material) of the NHP Regulations.";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:127:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 1 (plante ou matière végétale) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"85037";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:13:"Taxus baccata";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"AHN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:5:"PLANT";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";s:5:"title";s:17:"Taxus baccata_AHN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"197131";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:197132;a:25:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:19:"93715;101132;103663";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:0:"";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:94:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1 item 1 (plant or plant material) of the NHP Regulations.";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:127:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 1 (plante ou matière végétale) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:609:"The quantity or concentration of carvacrol in all applicable essential oils or extracts must be declared. 
Not applicable to whole herb preparations: Based on safety concerns, oregano oil intake of up to 0.27 micrograms/kg body weight per day is allowed. Applicants must provide evidence to support the safe use of the carvacrol content of oil of oregano, if they would like to use a higher quantity as a NMI in their product. If the daily exposure of carvacrol exceeds 0.23 micrograms/kg bw per day from the NHP in the absence of adequate safety evidence, the oil of oregano cannot be considered to be a NMI.";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:808:"La quantité ou concentration de carvacrol dans toutes les huiles ou extraits essentiels applicables doit être déclarée

En absence de donnés appuyant l’innocuité, l'huile d'origan ne peut pas être considérée comme ingrédient non médicinal si l'exposition quotidienne du carvacrol provenant du PSN dépasse 0.23 microgrammes /kg de poids corporel par jour.";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"85038";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:16:"Origanum vulgare";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"AHN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:5:"PLANT";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";s:5:"title";s:20:"Origanum vulgare_AHN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"197132";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:197133;a:24:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:876:"Velvet bean (Mucana pruriens) is an annual tropical plant, climbing shrub with long vines that can reach over 15 m.  The applicable part of this plant are the bean or seed and the hair on the bean pod.  These parts have been used medicinally in the formulation of products used mainly to maintain healthy cholesterol and blood sugar levels, as well as in traditional Ayurvedic Indian medicine for disease including Parkinson.  The active ingredient known to be present in Velvet bean is levodopa (L-dopa), which is well known for its action in the above mentioned medical conditions. The applicable part of Acai is the fruit or berry.  Since Acai is known to contain potent antioxidants, such as polyphenols and anthocyanins, it has been used orally for osteoarthritis, hypercholesterolemia and for improving general health; as well as a food in beverage (Acai juice) and in ice cream, jelly, and liquors. Rooibos is also known as Red bush tea, or simply Red tea which indicates to the colour of the brewed tea.. This bacteria is responsible for the flat sour taste of contaminated canned food, since it can grow at a pH as low as 4.2.  Accroding to the following papers (see below), this bacteria has some probiotic properties, since it was used as probiotic in piglets and chicken, where it demontrated growth promoting and prophylactic effects. of Propionibacteria can be found all over the body. Propionibacteria are generally nonpathogenic; however, when certain species of Propionibacteria contaminate blood and other body fluid, they can cause a number of infections including the common skin disease acne vulgaris (caused by P. acnes). Some species of Propionibacteria are found in food like cheeses and other dairy products. Propionibacterium freudenreichii is used in Swiss cheese manufacturing to produce its flavor and characteristic holes. The flavor derives from propionate, a product of fermentation, and the holes or "eyes" from bubbles of carbon dioxide. peltatum (Mayapple) is a herbaceous perrenial plant in the family Berberidaceae, native to the eastern part of North America.  Orally, Podophyllum has been used as a cathartic, for jaundice and liver ailments, fever, syphilis, and cancer; as well as an antidote for snake bites, abortifacient, and for hearing loss.  Topically, this plant is mostly used for the removal of topical warts.  All parts of the plant are known to be poisonous, except the fruit.  One of its active principles, Podophyllotoxin, is the pharmacological base for the known anti-cancer drug Etoposide.  Podophyllum for topical use is currently listed in Schedule F to the Food and Drug Regulations as follows: Podophyllum and the following extracts and active principles, when sold or recommended for topical use:
(a) podophyllotoxin

(Mitragyna speciosa) is a medicinal leaf harvested from a large tree native to Southeast Asia in the Rubiaceae family. Kratom contains many alkaloids including mitragynine, mitraphylline, and 7-hydroxymitragynine. Kratom also contains alkaloids found in uña de gato, which are thought to play a beneficial role on the immune system and lower blood pressure, as well as epicatechin, a powerful antioxidant also found in dark chocolate and closely related to the EGCG that gives green tea its beneficial effects. Other active chemicals in kratom include raubasine (best known from Rauwolfia serpentina) and some yohimbe alkaloids such as corynantheidine. Kratom has many potential medicinal uses, for example as a low grade analgesic comparable to codeine or propoxyphene, as a cheaper and potentially much safer alternative to methadone, and as a source of other chemicals with a wide range of beneficial activities which could be isolated from the psychoactive constituents. Kratom is a controlled substance in Thailand, Australia, Malaysia and Myanmar (Burma).  Kratom will be considered as a NHP, under schedule 1, item 1, Priority 4 (Plant).";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:94:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1 item 1 (plant or plant material) of the NHP Regulations.";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:127:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 1 (plante ou matière végétale) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"85082";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:18:"Mitragyna speciosa";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"AHN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:5:"PLANT";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";s:5:"title";s:22:"Mitragyna speciosa_AHN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"197173";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:197174;a:24:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:180:"Dictyophora indusiata is a stinkhorn fungus, eaten as a vegetable in some cuisines of southern China. The protistans have always been difficult to fit into the biological taxonomic hierarchy because their groups are ancestral to the plants, fungi, and animals, interrelationships are poorly understood, and often the groupings based on morphology and anatomy do not correspond to phylogenetic groupings. Ulkenia has been variously classified as a protozoan animal, a marine fungus, or a brown alga. While plants, animals, and fungi are clearly delineated in separate Kingdoms, it has been very difficult to do this with the protistans. Ulkenia is generally classified in a protistan Kingdom such as Chromista or Straminipila (also spelled Stramenopila). This common name (e.g. Morning glory) comes from the fact that the flowers of these plants opens at morning time, last for a single morning and dies in the afternoon, after which new flowers bloom each day.  This plant was originally used in China for the laxative properties of its seeds.  Nowadays, morning glory seeds are known for its content in the ergoline alkaloid d-Lysergic acid amide (Lysergamide, LSA, Ergine), which is structurally related to the controlled drugs d-Lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD, Lysergide) and Lysergic acid.  This class of compounds is well known for its hallucinogen properties.  In addition, the parent molecule of this family, Lysergic acid, is also known to be the precursor of these ergoline alkaloids, which are also produced by the ergot fungus. Since Morning glory is a naturally occurring plant, it meets the definition of a NHP; therefore, it will be considered as such, under Schedule 1, item 1 (Priority 4; Plant) of the NHP Regulations.";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:94:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1 item 1 (plant or plant material) of the NHP Regulations.";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:127:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 1 (plante ou matière végétale) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"85099";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:14:"Ipomoea indica";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"AHN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:5:"PLANT";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";s:5:"title";s:18:"Ipomoea indica_AHN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"197190";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:197191;a:25:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"94423";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:1147:"Morning glory is the common name given to a variety of flowering plant species in the family Convolvulaceae, including Rivea corymbosa L. and Ipomoea tricolor Cav.  This common name (e.g. Morning glory) comes from the fact that the flowers of these plants opens at morning time, last for a single morning and dies in the afternoon, after which new flowers bloom each day.  This plant was originally used in China for the laxative properties of its seeds.  Nowadays, morning glory seeds are known for its content in the ergoline alkaloid d-Lysergic acid amide (Lysergamide, LSA, Ergine), which is structurally related to the controlled drugs d-Lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD, Lysergide) and Lysergic acid.  This class of compounds is well known for its hallucinogen properties.  In addition, the parent molecule of this family, Lysergic acid, is also known to be the precursor of these ergoline alkaloids, which are also produced by the ergot fungus. Since Morning glory is a naturally occurring plant, it meets the definition of a NHP; therefore, it will be considered as such, under Schedule 1, item 1 (Priority 4; Plant) of the NHP Regulations.";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:94:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1 item 1 (plant or plant material) of the NHP Regulations.";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:127:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 1 (plante ou matière végétale) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"85100";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:16:"Ipomoea violacea";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"AHN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:5:"PLANT";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";s:5:"title";s:20:"Ipomoea violacea_AHN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"197191";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:197192;a:25:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"94423";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:1147:"Morning glory is the common name given to a variety of flowering plant species in the family Convolvulaceae, including Rivea corymbosa L. and Ipomoea tricolor Cav.  This common name (e.g. Morning glory) comes from the fact that the flowers of these plants opens at morning time, last for a single morning and dies in the afternoon, after which new flowers bloom each day.  This plant was originally used in China for the laxative properties of its seeds.  Nowadays, morning glory seeds are known for its content in the ergoline alkaloid d-Lysergic acid amide (Lysergamide, LSA, Ergine), which is structurally related to the controlled drugs d-Lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD, Lysergide) and Lysergic acid.  This class of compounds is well known for its hallucinogen properties.  In addition, the parent molecule of this family, Lysergic acid, is also known to be the precursor of these ergoline alkaloids, which are also produced by the ergot fungus. Since Morning glory is a naturally occurring plant, it meets the definition of a NHP; therefore, it will be considered as such, under Schedule 1, item 1 (Priority 4; Plant) of the NHP Regulations.";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:94:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1 item 1 (plant or plant material) of the NHP Regulations.";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:127:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 1 (plante ou matière végétale) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"85101";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:17:"Ipomoea hederacea";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"AHN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:5:"PLANT";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";s:5:"title";s:21:"Ipomoea hederacea_AHN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"197192";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:197193;a:25:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"94423";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:1147:"Morning glory is the common name given to a variety of flowering plant species in the family Convolvulaceae, including Rivea corymbosa L. and Ipomoea tricolor Cav.  This common name (e.g. Morning glory) comes from the fact that the flowers of these plants opens at morning time, last for a single morning and dies in the afternoon, after which new flowers bloom each day.  This plant was originally used in China for the laxative properties of its seeds.  Nowadays, morning glory seeds are known for its content in the ergoline alkaloid d-Lysergic acid amide (Lysergamide, LSA, Ergine), which is structurally related to the controlled drugs d-Lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD, Lysergide) and Lysergic acid.  This class of compounds is well known for its hallucinogen properties.  In addition, the parent molecule of this family, Lysergic acid, is also known to be the precursor of these ergoline alkaloids, which are also produced by the ergot fungus. pacifica_ABN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"197223";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:197224;a:25:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:24:"92631;98053;94423;107652";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:750:"Originally isolated by the German physiologist, microbiologist and physician Dr. Alfred Nissle in 1917 during WWI, while he was screening natural human E. coli isolates for inhibitory activity against enteropathogenic bacteria. This particular E. coli strain was isolated from the gut flora of a soldier who in contrast to his comrades did not show any symptoms of diarrhea and was therefore suspected to carry an endogenous E. coli strain with strong antagonistic activity to enteropathogenic microorganisms. The acceptance of E. coli strain Nissle 1917 as a probiotic, particularly in Europe, has dramatically increased in recent years [1-5]. E. coli strain Nissle 1917 will be considered as a NHP, under schedule 1, item 8, Priority 3 (Probiotic).";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:80:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1 item 8 (probiotic) of the NHP Regulations.";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:109:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 8 (probiotique) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"85133";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:28:"Escherichia coli Nissle 1917";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ABN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:4:"PROB";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";s:5:"title";s:32:"Escherichia coli Nissle 1917_ABN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"197224";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:197225;a:25:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"94423";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:332:"Haliotis iris is the binomial name for a specific species of abalone, known as Blackfoot abalone, Rainbow abalone or Paua abalone, where abalones are shellfishes (mollusks) from the Haliotidae family, Haliotis iris will be considered as a NHP, under Schedule 1, item 1 (Priority 3; However, Cantharis is also recognized as a common name for the insect itself; therefore, this classification will be based on the ingredient (the insect itself), not the homeopathic preparation.  The Spanish fly is an bronze-green beetle from the family Meloidae, originating from middle and southern Europe and in southwestern Asia.  It has been used medicinally for centuries mostly as an aphrodisiac, but also as a arbortifacient, stimulant and poison.  These medicinal properties are mostly due to its content (up to 5%) in Cantharidin, which is known as a poisonous chemical compound, since when ingested, the LD50 dose is around 0.5mg/Kg, with a dose as little as 10 mg being potentially fatal; which is the reason why Spanish fly is mostly used in relatively high diluted homeopathic preparations (known as Cantharis).  Despite these recognized safety concerns, Spanish fly meets the definition of a NHP and will be considered as such, under Schedule 1, item 1 (Priority 3; Non-human animal material) of the NHP Regulations.";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:96:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1 item 1 (non-human animal material) of the NHP Regulations.";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:157:"Consideré comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 1,matière animale autre qu'une matière provenant de l'humain, du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"85139";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:17:"Lytta vesicatoria";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ABN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:6:"NHANML";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";s:5:"title";s:21:"Lytta vesicatoria_ABN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"197229";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:197230;a:25:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"94423";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:578:"Edible black ant (Polyrhachis vicina Roger) is a traditional edible insect species in China. It has been used as a functional ingredient in various tonics or health foods.   Polyrhanchis vicina belongs to Formicinae; a subfamily within the Formicidae containing ants of moderate evolutionary development. One study determined the nutritional composition of the black ant, which included minerals, amino acids, superoxide dismutase (SOD), Vitamin E, and total acid. Polyrhachis vicina will be considered as a NHP, under Schedule 1, item 1, Priority 3 (Non-human animal material).";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:96:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1 item 1 (non-human animal material) of the NHP Regulations.";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:157:"Consideré comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 1,matière animale autre qu'une matière provenant de l'humain, du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"85140";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:18:"Polyrhachis vicina";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ABN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:6:"NHANML";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";s:5:"title";s:22:"Polyrhachis vicina_ABN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"197230";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:197231;a:25:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"94423";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:563:"Cryptotympana atrata (or Cicada) is the binomial name of an insect found in mainland China, Taiwan and Japan, which has been used as a traditional Chinese medicine for the treatment of fever, rashes and eye disorders.  The pharmaceutical substance used and obtained from this insect (nymph form) is called Periostracum cicadae (or Chan tui), prepared by removing the internal parts of the insect and grinding the empty shell.Cryptotympana atrata will be considered as a NHP, under Schedule 1, item 1 (Priority 3; Non-human animal material) of the NHP Regulations.";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:96:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1 item 1 (non-human animal material) of the NHP Regulations.";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:157:"Consideré comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 1,matière animale autre qu'une matière provenant de l'humain, du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"85141";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:20:"Cryptotympana atrata";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ABN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:6:"NHANML";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";s:5:"title";s:24:"Cryptotympana atrata_ABN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"197231";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:197232;a:25:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"94423";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:1480:"Chinese gall is the abnormal growth (gall) produced by parasitic aphids (insect) of Melaphis chinensis on the leaf or stems of Rhus chinensis (Chinese sumac), Rhus potaninii (potanin sumac) or Rhus punjabensis (red-punjab sumac), a deciduous dungarunga of the family Anacardiaceae. The gall aphid deposits a larva in leaves and stems of these trees and makes them produce the gall that looks like a hard and round excretions [1-2]. Galls (including Chinese gall) are rich in resins, tannic acid, and gallic acid [3-4]. Recent study shows the Chinese gall might exert anti-diabetic effect by suppressing carbohydrate absorption from intestine, and thereby reducing the postprandial increase of blood glucose [5]. Chinese gall will be considered as a NHP, under Schedule 1, item 1, Priority 4 (Plant material).

as an NHP under Schedule 1 item 1 (plant or plant material) of the NHP Regulations.";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:127:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 1 (plante ou matière végétale) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"85162";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:15:"Carlina acaulis";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"AHN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:5:"PLANT";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";s:5:"title";s:19:"Carlina acaulis_AHN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"197250";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:197251;a:25:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"94423";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:1515:"The silicon contents of bamboo vary widely from 0.3% to 9.95%. There is a clear trend that the silicon content of bamboo increases from stem, through branch, to leaves. It is also observed that the silica in bamboo roots (including Phyllostachys propinqua, Bambusa textilis, Racemobambos, Phyllostachys pubescen) is exclusively in the endodermis cells, but the silica in stem, branch and leaves of bamboo are accumulated mainly in epidermal cells. These observations support the idea that silicon enters bamboo as water-soluble monosilicic acid, Si(OH)4, which is transported subsequently through the root, stem, branch and leaves and polymerized and precipitated to form amorphous silica at tissue sites of these organs [1]. Another study showed the Pleioblastus chino also contains Silicon as amorphous hydrated silica (SiO2.nH2O) [2].
If applicant would like to apply for a product containg Bamboo as medicinal ingredient with the potency of Silicon or a product containg Silicon as a medicinal ingredient sourced from Bamboo, a certificate of analysis confirming the claimed amount of Silicon in the Bamboo is required.

References:
[1] T.P. Ding et al. ‘Silicon isotope fractionation in bamboo and its significance to the biogeochemical cycle of silicon’ 2008, Geochimica et Cosmochimica Acta, 72(5), pp. 1381-1395
[2] H. Motomura et. al. ‘Silica Deposition in Abaxial Epidermis before the Opening of Leaf Blades of Pleioblastus chino (Poaceae, Bambusoideae)’ 2006, Annals of Botany , 97, pp. cava [1-2] is a brown marine alga (seaweed) that is found abundantly in eastern Asia (Korea, Japan). Evidence has demonstrated that Ecklonia cava exhibits radical scavenging activity [3], matrix metalloproteinase inhibitory activity [4], bactericidal activity, protease inhibitory activity [5], antioxidative activity, and anti-inflammatory activity [6]. Ecklonia cava will be considered as a NHP, under schedule 1, item 1, Priority 3 (Alga).

dulcificum [1-3], a west african berry known as miracle fruit, is an evergreen bush or tree. The fruit is a small bright red, ellipsoid berry approximately 2–3 cm long and containing a single seed. When a single fruit is eaten prior to an acidic fruit such as lemon or lime, the aroma and inherent sweetness of the citrus remains but the sourness is almost completely disguised. Thus, development of miracle fruit as an artificial sweetener is continuing. The chemical responsible for this effect is ‘Miraculin’ (a glycoprotein). Recently, it has been found that miracle fruit may be used as an adjuvant for treating diabetic patients with insulin resistance because this fruit has the ability to improve insulin sensitivity [4]. Miracle fruit will be considered as a NHP, under schedule 1, item 1, Priority 4 (plant).

Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:736:"Not applicable to whole herb preparations: The quantity or concentration of carvacrol in all applicable essential oils or extracts must be declared. Based on safety concerns, thyme essential oil oral intake of up to 4.16 micrograms/kg body weight per day is allowed, and the daily oral exposure of carvacrol from the product must not exceed 0.23 micrograms/kg bw per day. If applicants would like to use a thyme essential oil or extract with a higher content of carvacrol as a non-medicinal ingredient (NMI) in their product, they must provide evidence to support its safe use. In the absence of adequate safety evidence, if the daily exposure of carvacrol exceeds the specified maximum, the ingredient cannot be considered to be a NMI.";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:958:"Non applicable au préparations à base de plantes complètes: La quantité ou concentration de carvacrol dans toutes les huiles ou extraits essentiels applicables doit être déclarée. Si les demandeurs veulent utiliser une huile essentielle ou extrait de thym qui contient une quantité élevée de carvacrol comme ingrédient non-médicinal dans leur produit, ils doivent fournir des preuves pour supporter son usage sécuritaire. Dans l’absence de preuves suffisantes appuyant l’innocuité, si l’exposition au carvacrol dépasse la valeur maximale spécifiée, l’ingrédient ne peut pas être considéré comme un ingrédient tamarisk (Tamarix gallica  L.) is a tree halophyte from the Tamaricaceae family found in coastal regions and desert [1,2,3]. This plant is known to possess astringent, detergent, diuretic, expectorant, and laxative properties; and to contain flavonoid sulphates, coniferyl alcohol derivatives, and proanthocyanidin sulphates in the stem bark and other aerial plant tissues [3]. The extract of Tamarix gallica has also shown to inhibit thioacetamide (TAA)-induced hepatic oxidative stress, toxicity and early tumor promotion response in male Wistar rats [4]. As a plant (i.e. tree), French tamarisk meets the substance aspect of the NHP definition, under Schedule 1, item 1 (Priority 4; Plant) of the NHP Regulations.
[1] http://www.itis.gov/servlet/SingleRpt/SingleRpt
[2] http://www.ars-grin.gov/cgi-bin/npgs/html/tax_search.pl
[3] Ksouri R. et al. Influence of biological, environmental and technical factors on phenolic content and antioxidant activities of Tunisian halophytes; C.R.Biologies 331 (2008) 865-873.
[4] Sehrawat A et al. Tamarix gallica ameliorates thioacetamide-induced hepatic oxidative stress and hyperproliferative response in Wistar rats; J. Enzyme Inhib. Med. Interestingly, Abies pectinata is not a recognized binomial name for Silver fir in the GRIN Taxonomy for Plants [2] (per se), Integrated Taxonomic Information System [3], and Entrez Taxonomy [4] websites. However, many hits found in Yahoo.com indicates that Abies pectinata is a synonym of Abies alba [5,6,7,8], which is a recognized binomial name in the above mentioned taxonomic websites with Silver fir as a common name. On teh other hand, Abies pectinata is recognized in other non-taxonomic references, such as the Personal Care Products Council on-line database [9]. As a tree, Silver fir (abies alba) meets the substance aspect of the NHP definition, under Schedule 1, item 1 (Priority 4; Plant) of the NHP Regulations.
