triflora";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"AHN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:5:"PLANT";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";s:5:"title";s:21:"Gentiana triflora_AHN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"197333";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:197334;a:25:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:17:"92984;94423;96157";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:2283:"Helmi Hussien/HC-SC/GC/CA wrote on 2009-05-29 05:56:38 PM: 
All members of the genus Pinctata (Pearl oysters) share the physiological properties that lead to the production of large pearls of commercial value, and attempts have been made to harvest pearls commercially from many of the species. However only some species are currently of significant commercial interest such as Pinctada margaritifera ( Black-lip Oyster), which is found in Persian Gulf and southwestern part of Indian Ocean. Black South Sea Pearls, or Tahitian pearls come from the Black-lip oyster. Pinctada (Pteria) margaritifera will be considered as a NHP, under schedule 1, item 1, Priority 3 (non-human animal material). 
Nacre (Hyriopsis cumingii), also known as mother of pearl or sadaf, is a naturally-occurring organic-inorganic composite. It is formed by layers of calcium carbonate (CaCO3) platelets (crystals), in the form of aragonite and conchiolin (a scleroprotein), separated by elastic biopolymers (such as chitin and lustrin). Nacre is secreted by the epithelial cells of the mantle tissue of certain species of mollusk. In these mollusks, nacre is continually deposited onto the inner surface of the animal's shell (the iridescent nacreous layer, commonly known as mother of pearl), both as a means to smooth the shell itself and as a defense against parasitic organisms and damaging detritus. Nacre will be considered as a NHP, under schedule 1, item 1, Priority 3 (non-human animal material). 
Freshwater pearls are a kind of pearl that comes from freshwater mussels. They are produced in Japan and the US on a limited scale, but are now almost exclusive to China. The grafting process was common when the industry mussel was primarily the cockscomb pearl mussel (Cristaria plicata). More than a decade ago the freshwater pearl industry of China shifted production from the cockscomb to the triangle shell mussel (Hyriopsis cumingii). Cristaria plicata (wrinkle shell or river shell) is a mussel which lives in the rivers and lakes of China, Vietnam, Japan, and Korea, and was the origin of the large volume of Chinese freshwater pearls produced during the 1970s and 1980s. Pearl (Cristaria plicata) will be considered as a NHP, under Schedule 1, item 1, Priority 3 (Non-human animal material).";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:96:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1 item 1 (non-human animal material) of the NHP Regulations.";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:158:"Consideré comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 1, matière animale autre qu'une matière provenant de l'humain, du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"85250";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:18:"Hyriopsis cumingii";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ABN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:6:"NHANML";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";s:5:"title";s:22:"Hyriopsis cumingii_ABN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"197334";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:197335;a:25:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:11:"92984;94423";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:2283:"Helmi Hussien/HC-SC/GC/CA wrote on 2009-05-29 05:56:38 PM: 
All members of the genus Pinctata (Pearl oysters) share the physiological properties that lead to the production of large pearls of commercial value, and attempts have been made to harvest pearls commercially from many of the species. However only some species are currently of significant commercial interest such as Pinctada margaritifera ( Black-lip Oyster), which is found in Persian Gulf and southwestern part of Indian Ocean. Black South Sea Pearls, or Tahitian pearls come from the Black-lip oyster. Pinctada (Pteria) margaritifera will be considered as a NHP, under schedule 1, item 1, Priority 3 (non-human animal material). 
Nacre (Hyriopsis cumingii), also known as mother of pearl or sadaf, is a naturally-occurring organic-inorganic composite. It is formed by layers of calcium carbonate (CaCO3) platelets (crystals), in the form of aragonite and conchiolin (a scleroprotein), separated by elastic biopolymers (such as chitin and lustrin). Nacre is secreted by the epithelial cells of the mantle tissue of certain species of mollusk. In these mollusks, nacre is continually deposited onto the inner surface of the animal's shell (the iridescent nacreous layer, commonly known as mother of pearl), both as a means to smooth the shell itself and as a defense against parasitic organisms and damaging detritus. Nacre will be considered as a NHP, under schedule 1, item 1, Priority 3 (non-human animal material). 
Freshwater pearls are a kind of pearl that comes from freshwater mussels. They are produced in Japan and the US on a limited scale, but are now almost exclusive to China. The grafting process was common when the industry mussel was primarily the cockscomb pearl mussel (Cristaria plicata). More than a decade ago the freshwater pearl industry of China shifted production from the cockscomb to the triangle shell mussel (Hyriopsis cumingii). Cristaria plicata (wrinkle shell or river shell) is a mussel which lives in the rivers and lakes of China, Vietnam, Japan, and Korea, and was the origin of the large volume of Chinese freshwater pearls produced during the 1970s and 1980s. Pearl (Cristaria plicata) will be considered as a NHP, under Schedule 1, item 1, Priority 3 (Non-human animal material).";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:96:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1 item 1 (non-human animal material) of the NHP Regulations.";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:158:"Consideré comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 1, matière animale autre qu'une matière provenant de l'humain, du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"85251";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:17:"Cristaria plicata";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"ABN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:6:"NHANML";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";s:5:"title";s:21:"Cristaria plicata_ABN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"197335";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:197336;a:25:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:11:"92983;94423";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:1071:"Helmi Hussien/HC-SC/GC/CA wrote on 2009-05-29 01:07:30 PM:
Rubus Chingii (Chinese or Palmleaf raspberry) is a plant native to China (USDA 2009). It been used as a food and tonic in traditional Chinese medicine. Chinese raspberry has anti-oxidative, hepatoprotective, and immunomodulatory properties, and has effects on the hypothalamus–pituitary–sex gland axis. Fruits of Chinese raspberry contain seven triterpene acids which were characterized spectroscopically as oleanolic acid, ursolic acid, maslinic acid, 2α-hydroxyursolic acid, arjunic acid, 2α,3α,19α-trihydroxy-12-oleanen-28-oic acid, and euscaphic acid (Guo, Gao et al. 2005). Rubus Chingii will be considered as a NHP, under schedule 1, item 1, Priority 4 (plant).  References:  Guo, Q. L., J. Y. Gao, et al. (2005). "Analysis of bioactive triterpenes from Rubus chingii by cyclodextrin-modified capillary electrophoresis." Chromatographia 62(3-4): 145-150. 
USDA. (2009). Atriplex halimus, also known as Saltbush, a plant from the Chenopodiaceae family (Global Biodiversity Information Facility), is a native shrub from Jordan, and is used for rangeland reclamation in Mediterranean desert shrublands (El-Shatnawi, 2002). It has many medicinal properties, including anti-diabetic effect (Said, 2008). Atriplex halimus will be considered as an NHP, under Item 1(plant material) of Schedule 1 of the NHP regulations.References:El-Shatnawi MKJ, Turuk M. 2002. Dry matter accumulation and chemical content of saltbush (atriplex halimus) grown in mediterranean desert shrublands. New Zealand Journal of Agricultural Reserach. 45(3): 139-144 
Global Biodiversity Information Facility,http://data.gbif.org/welcome.htm 
Said O, Fulder S, Khalil K, Azaizeh H, Kassis E, Saad B. 2008. Maintaining a physiological blood glucose level with 'glucolevel', a combination of four anti-diabetes plants used in the traditional arab herbal medicine. Setaria italica, also known as foxtail millet from the Poaceae family (USDA GRIN) is one of the oldest domesticated dry farming crops from Eurasia and is considered to form the oldest cultivated foods known to humans (Lu, 2009). It will be considered as an NHP, under item 1 of Schedule 1 of the NHP regs.

References: 
USDA GRIN: http://www.ars-grin.gov/cgi-bin/npgs/html/taxon.pl?3381

Chlorella regularis is a species of fresh water green algae Chlorella (NCBI 2009)(GBIF 2009)(Guiry 2009). Like other species of Chlorella, it will be considered as a NHP, under schedule 1, item 1, Priority 3 (Alga).

Proper name: Genista tinctoria 
Common name: Dyer’s greenweed 
Other common names: Woodwaxen; Dyer's broom 
Genista tinctoria (NCBI 2009) is a plant species of the genus Genista (USDA 2009) (ITIS 2009). The entire plant has medicinal applications. It acts as a purifier, cathartic, diuretic, purgative, emetic. It also increases heart rate, strengthens the walls of blood vessels, stimulates kidney blood circulation, and affects metabolism. Genista tinctoria contains quinolizidine alkaloids, including methylcytisine, anagyrine, isopsparteine, lupanine, tinctorin, and cysisine. It also contains flavonoids (including luteolin glycosides), isoflavonoids (including genistein and genistin), and lectins (Gruenwald, Brendler et al. 2004). Genista tictoria will be considered as a NHP, under schedule 1, item 1, Priority 4 (Plant).

References: 
Gruenwald, J., T. Brendler, et al. (2004). PDR for Herbal Medicines, Thomson PDR

USDA. (2009). Chlorella vulgaris is one of the main species of fresh water green algae Chlorella (NCBI 2009)(GBIF 2009)(Guiry 2009). It grows in fresh water throughout the world (Fundukian 2009). Chlorella vulgaris will be considered as a NHP, under schedule 1, item 1, Priority 3 (Alga).

"Taxonomy Resources." from http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/Taxonomy/taxonomyhome.html/index.cgi?chapter=resources.";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:75:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1 item 1 (alga) of the NHP Regulations.";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:103:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 1 (algue) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:71:"The only acceptable source material for this ingredient is broken cell.";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:79:"La seule matière d'origine acceptable pour cet ingrédient est Celule brisée.";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"85259";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:18:"Chlorella vulgaris";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"AHN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:4:"ALGA";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";s:5:"title";s:22:"Chlorella vulgaris_AHN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"197343";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:197344;a:25:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:11:"93084;94423";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:635:"Tinospora sinensis (Lour.) Merr., Menispermaceae (USDA 2009) 
Tinospora sinensis or “kuan jin teng” (Bensky et al. 2004) is a herb with bitter, slightly cold properties used in Traditional Chinese Medicine (TCM). Specifically, it dispels wind-dampness and relaxes the sinews (for hot painful obstruction such as cramping and stiffness) and relaxes the sinews and unblocks the channels (for redness, swelling, heat, and pain associated with traumatic injury). It can be applied topically in treatment of injury to the bones and sinews. T. sinensis is contraindicated in pregnant and post partum women (Bensky et al. 2004). Tinospora";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:94:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1 item 1 (plant or plant material) of the NHP Regulations.";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:127:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 1 (plante ou matière végétale) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"85260";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:18:"Tinospora sinensis";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"AHN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:5:"PLANT";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";s:5:"title";s:22:"Tinospora sinensis_AHN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"197344";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:197345;a:25:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:11:"93084;94423";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:942:"Siegesbeckia orientalis L., Siegiesbeckia pubescens Makino (Bensky et al. 2004) 
Siegesbeckia orientalis or “xi xian cao” is indicated to dispel wind-dampness and unblock the channels and collaterals, used for spasms and cramps in the extremities, numbness in the extremities, weak legs and wind-stroke (Bensky et al. 2004). Siegesbeckia orientalis is contraindicated when patients have numbness or painful obstruction of the limbs, aching within the bones and weakness of the knees and lower back due to spleen or kidney deficiency or deficiency of yin and blood, rather than as a result of attack by wind or dampness (Bensky et al. 2004).  The recommended dosage is 9-15 g/day decoction. The daily dose of Siegesbeckia orientalis (900 mg) in Arthro-Ace is considerably less than the recommended dose indicated in the literature. Therefore, it is not likely that Siegesbeckia orientalis would contribute significantly to the health risk.";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:94:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1 item 1 (plant or plant material) of the NHP Regulations.";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:127:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 1 (plante ou matière végétale) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"85261";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:22:"Sigesbeckia orientalis";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"AHN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:5:"PLANT";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";s:5:"title";s:26:"Sigesbeckia orientalis_AHN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"197345";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:197346;a:25:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:11:"93084;94423";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:583:"Ardisia gigantifolia Stapf, Myrsinaceae (IPNI 2009) 
Aridisia gigantifolia or “zou ma tai” is indicated to remove wind-dampness, tonify tendons and bones, invigorate blood and remove stasis and is used for arthritis pain and injury. The recommended dosage is 50-100 g fresh (1-2 liang) or 15-25 g dried (3-5 qian) decoction (JNMC 1997). The daily dose of Ardisia gigantifolia (600 mg) in Arthro-Ace is considerably less than the recommended dose indicated in the literature. Therefore, it is not likely that Ardisia gigantifolia would contribute significantly to the health risk.";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:94:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1 item 1 (plant or plant material) of the NHP Regulations.";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:127:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 1 (plante ou matière végétale) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"85262";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:20:"Ardisia gigantifolia";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"AHN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:5:"PLANT";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";s:5:"title";s:24:"Ardisia gigantifolia_AHN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"197346";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:197347;a:25:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:11:"93084;94423";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:803:"Speranskia tuberculata Baill., Euphorbiaceae (IPNI 2009)
S. tuberculata acts to remove wind and dampness, smooth the channels, invigorate the blood, and alleviate pain. It is indicated in the treatment of arthritic pain. The recommended dose of the decoction is 3 – 5 qián or 9 – 15 g/day (JNMC 1997), using a conversion of 1 qián to 3 g (Editorial Board of Comprehensive Chinese Materia Medica 1998). The dosage forms are not directly comparable (i.e. decoction vs. pill) since preparation methods were not specified (e.g. aqueous extract or dried powder). However, the daily dose of S. tuberculata in Arthro-Ace (600 mg) is considerable less than the recommended dose indicated in the literature. Therefore, it is not likely that S. tuberculata would contribute significantly to the health risk.";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:94:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1 item 1 (plant or plant material) of the NHP Regulations.";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:127:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 1 (plante ou matière végétale) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"85263";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:22:"Speranskia tuberculata";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"AHN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:5:"PLANT";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";s:5:"title";s:26:"Speranskia tuberculata_AHN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"197347";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:197348;a:25:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:11:"93084;94423";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:1482:"Homalomena occulta (Lour.) Schott, Araceae (USDA 2009)
H. occulta or “qian nian jian” dispels wind-dampness and strengthens the sinews and bones: for patterns of wind-cold-damp painful obstruction with pain, spasms, or numbness, either in the sinews or the bones. Because of its strong fortifying actions, H. occulta is also suitable for weakness or softness in the sinews and bones. It is widely used for treating the elderly, both as an external wash and for internal use and for pain and swelling due to traumatic injury. It is contraindicated in individuals with internal heat due to yin deficiency. Bensky et al. (2004) indicate that toxic effects occurring in two patients who developed symptoms of toxicity including nausea, vomiting, vertigo, spasma, unconsciousness, and incontinence of stool and urine after administration of a decoction in which this substance was considered to be the most likely cause. No further details of these reports are provided, including dosage and route of administration. The recommended dose of the decoction is 4.5 – 9 g/day (Bensky et al. 2004). The dosage forms are not directly comparable (i.e. decoction vs. pill) since preparation methods were not specified (e.g. aqueous extract or dried powder). However, the daily dose of H. occulta in Arthro-Ace (300 mg) is considerably less than the recommended dose indicated in the literature. Therefore, it is not likely that H. occulta would contribute significantly to the health risk.";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:94:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1 item 1 (plant or plant material) of the NHP Regulations.";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:127:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 1 (plante ou matière végétale) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"85264";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:18:"Homalomena occulta";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"AHN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:5:"PLANT";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";s:5:"title";s:22:"Homalomena occulta_AHN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"197348";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:197349;a:25:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:11:"93184;94423";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:3218:"Pterocarpus santalinus (commonly known as Red sandalwood or Red sanders), native to India, is a leguminous tree of the family Fabaceae (ITIS 2009, USDA 2009). Eight flavonoids were identified from the flowers of Inula britannica (luteolin, diosmetin, chrysoeriol, kaempferol, quercetin, 6-hydroxyluteolin-6-methyl ether, spinacetin and eupatin) and exhibited considerable antioxidant activity (Bai, Zhou et al. 2005). Inula britannica will be considered as a NHP, under schedule 1, item 1, Priority 4 (plant).

To: NHPOLS-ITS 
cc: Robin Marles/HC-SC/GC/CA@HWC, Martin Charron/HC-SC/GC/CA@HWC, Austin Vair/HC-SC/GC/CA@HWC
Subject Re: [NHP Ingredients DB - Support - Data #874] (New) Add Colocasia Esculenta (Taro) as MI

Colocasia esculenta is a vegetatively propagated root crop belonging to the plant family Araciae and having a long history of food use, especially in Southeast Asia and the Pacific, for its high content in starch, proteins, and minerals (ITIS 2009, NCBI 2009, USDA 2009, Quero-Garcia et al. 2009, Lu et al. 2008, Perez et al. 2007, Lin and Jeang 2005, Kreike et al. 2004, Ejoh et al. 1996, Gubag et al. 1996, Hirai et al. 1993). In contrast to its apparent beneficial food properties, Taro is also known as a nuisance weed in the wild and consequently, several methods have been investigated to eradicate such weed infestation, such as solid-feed anaerobic digesters and vermicomposting (Bindu and Ramasamy 2008, Kurien and Ramasamy 2006).

Particular compounds isolated or found in Taro include phytocystatins, monogalactosyldiacylglycerols and digalactosyldiacylglycerols, lectins, as well as anthocyanins such as cyanidin 3-glucoside, pelargonidin 3-glucoside, and cyanidin 3-rhamnoside; molecules, among the ones mentioned above, that have been associated with antifungal, antihypercholesterolemia, antioxidative and anti-cancer properties (Wang et al. 2008, Terasawa et al. 2007, Yang and Yeh 2005, Sakano et al. 2005, Brown et al. 2005).

Based on the information presented above, Colocasia esculenta meets the substance aspect of the NHP definition, under Schedule 1, item 1 (Priority 4; Plant), as outlined in the NHP Regulations (Justice Canada 2009). As heavy metals (e.g. arsenic, cadmium, and mercury) absorption or uptake from contaminated soil has been observed and quantified as higher than WHO acceptable daily intake in Colocasia esculenta (Essumang et al. 2007), these chemical contaminants should be of particular attention in quality assessment.

References:

Bindu T., Ramasamy E.V. 2008. Recovery of energy from Taro (Colocasia esculenta) with solid-feed anaerobic digesters (SOFADs). Waste Management 28: 396-405.

Brown A.C., Reitzenstein J.E., Liu J., Jadus M.R. 2005. The Anti-Cancer Effects of Poi (Colocasia esculenta) on Colonic Adenocarcinoma Cells In Vitro. Phytotherapy Research 19: 767-771.

dioica (Cat’s foot) is a flowering plant in the family Asteraceae (KI/GCI/APNI 2004; ITIS 2009; NCBI 2009). It is found in the cool regions of Europe and Asia and also in Alaska (USDA 2009). Cat’s foot is used as an antibacterial, antispasmodic, cholagogue, choleretic, discutient, diuretic, immunostimulant, and phagocytotic (Duke 2002). Cat’s foot will be considered as a NHP, under schedule 1, item 1, Priority 4 (Plant).

djambianum (golden fern- penghawar) is a plant belonging to the family Cibotiaceae (Quattrocchi 2000). CRC World Dictionary of Plant Names: Common Names, Scientific Names, Eponyms, Synonyms, and Etymology, CRC";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:94:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1 item 1 (plant or plant material) of the NHP Regulations.";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:127:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 1 (plante ou matière végétale) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"85318";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:19:"Cibotium djambianum";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"AHN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:5:"PLANT";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";s:5:"title";s:23:"Cibotium djambianum_AHN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"197402";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:197403;a:25:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:11:"92860;94423";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:3549:"Proper name: Trichilia catigua (USDA 2009)
Common names: Catuaba (USDA 2009),Catigua (USDA 2009)

Trichilia catigua, commonly known as Catuaba, is a plant native to Southern america, mostly Brazil, and belonging to the family Meliaceae (USDA 2009).

Experimentally, the hydroalcoholic bark extract of this plant has shown antidepressant-like and antinociceptive effects in mice and rats (Viana et al. 2009, Campos et al. 2005), as well as antioxidant properties in vitro (Tang et al. 2007); activities associated in part or in whole with the active principles isolated from or known to be present in the plant, such as bioflavonoids which can be quantified using UV spectrophotometry (Rolim et al. 2005, Baby et al. 2006); or more specifically epicatechins such as Catiguanin A and B (Tang et al. 2007).

Clinically, Oliveira et al. (2005) have studied the clinical toxicology of an herbal medicinal product, known as Catuama® and composed as medicinal ingredient of the aqueous extract of Paullinia cupana (1.25 mL), Tricilia catigua (0.875 mL), Ptychopetalum olacoides (0.875 mL), and Zingiber officinale (0.2 mL), administered daily (25 mL per dose) for 4 weeks in healthy volunteers and showed no noticeable toxic effect.

Based on the above information, Trichilia catigua meets the substance aspect of the natural health product (NHP) definition, as outlined in the NHP Regulations (Justice Canada 2009).

References:

Baby A.R., Maciel C.P.M., Kaneko T.M., Velasco M.V.R. 2006. UV Spectrophotometric Determination of Bioflavonoids from a Semisolid Pharmaceutical Dosage Form Containing Trichilia catigua Adr. Juss and Ptychopetalum olacoides Bentham Standardized Extract: Analytical Method Validation and Statistical Procedures. Journal of AOAC International 89(6): 1532-1537.

Juss (Meliaceae) and Ptychopetalum olacoides Bentham (Olacaceae) Commercial Extract. Journal of AOAC International 88(4): 1015-1019.

Antinociceptive Activity of Trichilia catigua Hydroalcoholic Extract: New Evidence on its Dopaminergic Effects. Evid. Based Complement. Alternat. Med. eCAM Advance Access published October 8.";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:94:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1 item 1 (plant or plant material) of the NHP Regulations.";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:127:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 1 (plante ou matière végétale) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"85319";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:17:"Trichilia catigua";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"AHN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:5:"PLANT";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";s:5:"title";s:21:"Trichilia catigua_AHN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"197403";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:197404;a:25:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:11:"92860;94423";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:6314:"Proper name: Angelica keiskei (USDA 2009)
Common name: Ashitaba (USDA 2009)

Angelica keiskei, commonly known as Ashitaba in Japan, is a plant belonging to the family Apiaceae (USDA 2009).

Experimentally, Ashitaba, its extracts and/or active principles such as the chalcones xanthoangelol, 4-hydroxyderricin, xanthoangelol B, D, E, and F, isobavachalcone, as well as the flavone cynaroside and the coumarin laserpitin, has shown antibacterial (Inamori et al. 1991), vasorelaxant (Matsuura et al. 2001), antihypertensive and lipid regulating (Nagata et al. 2007, Ogawa et al. 2007, Ogawa et al. 2005a, Ogawa et al. 2005b, Ogawa et al. 2003, Park et al. 2002, Shimizu et al. 1999), anti-inflammatory (Sugii et al. 2005), antidiabetic (Enoki et al. 2007), superoxide-scavenging (Aoki et al. 2008), as well as antitumor and antimetastatic (Motani et al. 2008, Nishimura et al. 2007, Kwon et al. 2006, Akihisa et al. 2006, Tabata et al. 2005, Kimura et al. 2004, Akihisa et al. 2003, Kimura and Baba 2003) activities.

Based on the above information, Angelica keiskei meets the substance aspect of the natural health product (NHP) definition, as outlined in the NHP Regulations (Justice Canada 2009).

Tambourissa trichophylla (Ambora) is a plant from family Monimiaceae found in Madagascar (GBIF 2009) (KI/GCI/APNI 2004). It has been used in traditional medicine. It is also used in cosmetics as a skin conditioning agent (Gottschalck and Bailey 2008). Three flavonol O-glycosides were isolated from T. trichophylla extracts (Lhuillier 2007). Tambourissa trichophylla will be considered as a NHP, under schedule 1, item 1, Priority 4 (plant).

naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"85379";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:16:"Mimulus guttatus";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"AHN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:5:"PLANT";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";s:5:"title";s:20:"Mimulus guttatus_AHN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"197461";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:197462;a:25:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:11:"93281;94423";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:1072:"Mosla chinensis is a plant species, commonly known as shi xiang ru, which has been used in folklore medicine (USDA 2009). The majority of its constituents reside in its essential oil, mainly as carvacrol and thymol (Zhu 1992).
As such, Mosla chinensis meets the substance aspect of the natural health product (NHP) definition, as outlined in the NHP Regulations (Government of Canada 2009).
References:
Government of Canada 2009. Natural Health Products Regulations. URL: http://laws.justice.gc.ca/en/showtdm/cr/SOR-2003-196//?showtoc=&instrumentnumber=SOR-2003-196 [Accessed 2009-12-04].

National Germplasm Resources Laboratory, Beltsville, Maryland. URL: http://www.ars-grin.gov/cgi-bin/npgs/html/index.pl?language=en [Accessed 2009-12-04].
Zhu G.P. 1992. [Comparison of chemical constituents of essential oils from Elsholtzia splendens and cultivated Mosla chinensis by GC-MS analysis]. 
Yao Xue Xue Bao 27(4):287-93. [Only abstract available].

niger";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"AHN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:5:"PLANT";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";s:5:"title";s:20:"Helleborus aggregata is a plant species, commonly known as wu yao, with an economical importance in folklore medicine, such as in traditional Chinese medicine (USDA 2009). Compounds isolated from the roots or leaves of this plant, such as neolindenenonelactone, linderagalactones A to E, or secoaggregatalactone A, respectively, have shown hepatoprotective activity in a human hepatoma cell line, Hep G2 (Gan et al. 2009, Lin et al. 2007, Chen et al. 2007).

As the above information indicates, Lindera aggregata meets the substance aspect of the natural health product (NHP) definition, as outlined in the NHP Regulations (Government of Canada 2009).

References:

Gan L.-S., Zheng Y.-L., Mo J.-X., Liu X., Li X.-H., Zhou C.-X. 2009. Sesquiterpene Lactones from the Root Tubers of Lindera aggregata. J. Nat. Prod. 72: 1497-5001.

Helmi";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:94:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1 item 1 (plant or plant material) of the NHP Regulations.";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:127:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 1 (plante ou matière végétale) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"85399";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:17:"Lindera aggregata";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"AHN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:5:"PLANT";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";s:5:"title";s:21:"Lindera aggregata_AHN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"197481";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:197482;a:25:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:11:"93552;94423";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:1850:"Caesalpinia sappan (Sappanwood) (ITIS 2009) is a flowering plant (from family Leguminosae) native to Southeast Asia and Malay Archipelago (islands between south eastern Asia and Australia) (USDA 2009) (GBIF 2009). C. sappan contains many chemical constituents including homoisoflavans (Zhao, Bai et al. 2008), phanginin diterpenoids (Yodsaoue, Cheenpracha et al. 2008), sappanins and sappanones (Nguyen, Awale et al. 2005), brazilin and brazilein (red dye components) (Kim, Baek et al. 1997) (Fuke, Yamahara et al. 1985), etc. Some of these constituents act as: analgesic, cytoprotective, vasorelaxative, antioxidant, anti-acne, anti-allergic, anti-influenza, anti-inflammatory, and antibacterial. Caesalpinia sappan will be considered as a NHP, under schedule 1, item 1, Priority 4 (plant).

Compounds isolated from this plant, such as lantanolic acid, experimentally showed inhibitory activity against nuclear factor of activated T cells (NFAT) transcription factor, indicative of their potential in treating immune diseases (Dat et al. 2004).
According to the information outlined above, Liquidambar formosana meets the substance aspect of the natural health product (NHP) definition, as outlined in the NHP Regulations (Government of Canada 2009).

The roots of Glehnia littorales are consumed as tonics in
China and Japan in the form of soup or medicine as a diaphoretic, an antipyretic, and an analgesic and aerial parts are used for salads and as an aromatic vegetable (Miyazawa 2001, Ng 2004). It has been shown to possess antibacterial, antifungal and antioxidant properties (Ng 2004). Glehnia littoralis will be considered as an NHP, under item 1 (plant material) of Schedule 1 of the NHP regs.

The leaves of Clematis montana have been utilized for the treatment of skin diseases in India. A novel mannose-binding lectin (CML) was isolated from Clematis montana stem which shows antiviral and apoptosis-inducing activities (Peng, Lv et al. 2009). Two triterpene glycosides designated as montanosides 1 and 2 which isolated from extract of Clematis montana, showed potent cytotoxic activity against the test cells (Jangwan and Dobhal 2008). Many saponins, such as Clemontanosides B, C, E, and F, were also isolated from this plant [e.g. (Thapliyal and Bahuguna 1993)]. Recently, many other constituents of C. Montana including 14 known chemicals, such as caffeic acid, vanillin and hyperin, were isolated (Cheng-Zhi, Yue-Hu et al. 2008). Clematis Montana will be considered as a NHP, under schedule 1, item 1, Priority 4 (plant).

Microcos paniculata will be considered as a NHP, under schedule 1, item 1, Priority 4 (plant).

Compounds isolated from this plant, namely chalcones, have been shown to possess antioxidant and anticancer properties, and studies with the aqueous extract from the flower buds of this plant have given promising results for the prevention and treatment of diabetes (Mai 2007).
Cleistocalyx operculatus will be considered as an NHP, under item 1 (plant material) of Schedule 1 of the NHP regs.

As per the information outlined above, Piper guineense meets the substance aspect of the Natural Health Product (NHP) definition, under Schedule 1, item 1 (Plant) of the NHP Regulations (Government of Canada 2010).

As per the information outlined above, Lessonia nigrescens meets the substance aspect of the Natural Health Product (NHP) definition, under Schedule 1, item 1 (Alga) of the NHP Regulations (Government of Canada 2010).

Common name(s): Clavo huasco

Tynanthus panurensis is a large woody plant that belongs to the Bignoniaceae family and grows in the Amazon rainforest (IPNI 2010, Plaza et al. 2005). It is reported to be used traditionally as an aphrodisiac, tonic, energiser, analgesic, and to treat rheumatism and diabetes (Plaza et al. 2005).

As per the above information, Tynanthus panurensis meets the Natural Health Product (NHP) definition, under item 1 (plant) of Schedule 1 to the NHP Regulations (Government of Canada 2010).

References:

Government of Canada 2010. Natural Health Products Regulations. URL: http://laws.justice.gc.ca/en/showtdm/cr/SOR-2003-196//?showtoc=&instrumentnumber=SOR-2003-196 [Accessed 2010-01-27].

IPNI 2010. International Plant Name Index. URL: http://www.ipni.org/ [Accessed 2010-01-27].

Plaza A., Montoro P., Benavides A., Pizza C., Piacente S. 2005. Phenylpropanoid Glycosides from Tynanthus panurensis: Characterization and LC-MS Quantitative Analysis. J. Agric. Food Chem. 53: 2853-2858.

Common name(s): Bois bandé

Richeria grandis, also known as Bois bandé, is a flowering plant that belongs to the Euphorbiaceae family (IOPI 2010, IPNI 2010). It is an important component of the cloud forest in parts of South America and has been used in local populations for erectile dystunction and as aphrodisiac (Lans 2007, Cuenca et al. 1991).

Based on the above, Richeria grandis meets the Natural Health Product (NHP) definition, under item 1 (plant) of Schedule 1 to the NHP Regulations (Government of Canada 2010).

References:

Cuenca G., Herrera R., Merida T. 1991. Distribution of aluminium in accumulator plants by X-ray microanalysis in Richeria grandis Vahl leaves from a cloud forest in Venezuela. Plant, Cell and Environment 41: 437-441.

Lans C. 2007. Ethnomedicines used in Trinidad and Tobago for reproductive problems. This plant has been used in traditional medicine for the treatment of rheumatism, influenza, gastrointestinal diseases, as well as for skin cancer. These biological activities are believed to be due, at least in part, to the triterpenes content of this plant, many of which have been isolated from the stem bark, leaves, and/or roots of Maytenus macrocarpa (Torpocco et al. 2007, Chavez et al. 2000, Chavez et al. 1999, Chavez et al. 1998).

As per the information outlined above, Maytenus macrocarpa meets the substance aspect of the Natural Health Product (NHP) definition, under Schedule 1, item 1 (Plant) of the NHP Regulations (Government of Canada 2010).

URL: http://www.ipni.org/ [Accessed 2010-02-04].";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:94:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1 item 1 (plant or plant material) of the NHP Regulations.";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:127:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 1 (plante ou matière végétale) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"85414";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:20:"Aframomum stipulatum";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"AHN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:5:"PLANT";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";s:5:"title";s:24:"Aframomum stipulatum_AHN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"197496";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:197497;a:25:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:11:"93687;94423";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:2004:"Proper name(s): Pseudognaphalium obtusifolium, Gnaphalium obtusifolium
Common name(s): Catfoot, Eastern rabbit-tobacco, Fragrant cudweed, Fragrant everlasting

Gnaphalium obtusifolium is a flowering plant that has been used in traditional medicine, especially in Native American groups where it plays both a spiritual and medicinal role (USDA 2010, Jackson 2002). It is burnt with other plants after funerals, and during baby naming ceremonies. From a medicinal point of view, it is used to treat a series of conditions including insomnia, nervousness, sore throats, pneumonia, colds, fevers, upset stomach, abnominal cramps, asthma, flu, cough, rheumatism, bowel disorders, and mouth ulcers among others (Jackson 2002).

Based on the above, Gnaphalium obtusifolium meets the substance aspect of the Natural Health Product (NHP) definition, under item 1 (Plant) of Schedule 1 to the NHP Regulations (Government of Canada 2010).

References:

Government of Canada 2010. Natural Health Products Regulations. URL: http://laws.justice.gc.ca/en/showtdm/cr/SOR-2003-196//?showtoc=&instrumentnumber=SOR-2003-196 [Accessed 2010-01-27].

Jackson J.B. 2002. Spirit medicine: Native American uses of common everlasting (Pseudognaphalium obtusifolium) in eastern North America. Occasional Papers of the Sam Noble Oklahoma Museum of Natural History 13:1–17.

As for the second ingredient, Tilia officinalis, this name could not be found in any authoritative taxonomic references; and therefore, clarification from the applicant, or from the information found in the file, is required in order to confirm, for example, if the plant in question could be one of the more common types of Tilia species, namely Tilia cordata or Tilia x europaea.";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:94:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1 item 1 (plant or plant material) of the NHP Regulations.";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:127:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 1 (plante ou matière végétale) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"85415";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:29:"Pseudognaphalium obtusifolium";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"AHN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:5:"PLANT";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";s:5:"title";s:33:"Pseudognaphalium obtusifolium_AHN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"197497";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:197498;a:25:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:11:"93757;94423";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:1814:"The term 'Peioil', from the ingredient 'Lychee Fruit Peioil' associated with this request, has not been found and therefore, additional information is required in order to know the exact preparation. For the time being however, the following is the classification for Lychee, the plant most likely associated with this ingredient:

Litchi chinensis (Lychee) is a plant from the family Sapindaceae native to China and India (ITIS 2010, NCBI 2010, USDA 2010). It contains levulinic, malic, citric, lactic, malonic, fumaric, succinic, phosphoric, and glutaric acids. The bark of lychee contains friedelin and stigmasterol. Besides many reducing and non-reducing sugars, the Lychee aril contains 34.5-45.4 mg/kg ascorbic acid (Khare 2007).

Based on the above information, Litchi chinensis meets the substance aspect of the Natural Health Product (NHP) definition, under Schedule 1, item 1 (Plant) of the NHP Regulations (Government of Canada 2010).

Based on the above, Fragaria virginiana meets the substance aspect of the Natural Health Product (NHP) definition, under Schedule 1, item 1 (plant) of the NHP Regulations (Government of Canada 2010).

URL: http://www.ars-grin.gov/cgi-bin/npgs/html/index.pl?language=en [Accessed 2010-02-11].";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:94:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1 item 1 (plant or plant material) of the NHP Regulations.";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:127:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 1 (plante ou matière végétale) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"85417";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:19:"Fragaria virginiana";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"AHN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:5:"PLANT";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";s:5:"title";s:23:"Fragaria virginiana_AHN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"197499";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:197500;a:25:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:11:"93686;94423";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:1501:"roper name(s): Elephantopus scaber (USDA 2010)
Common name(s): Didancao (But et al. 1997)

Elephantopus scaber belongs to the family Asteraceae and is traditionally known in Chinese medicine as 'Didancao', where it is used as a diuretic, an antifebrile, antiviral and antibacterial agent, as well as for the treatment of hepatitis, bronchitis, cough and arthralgia, scabies, gastropathy, among others (USDA 2010, Ahmad et al. 2009, But et al. 1996).

Based on the above, Elephantopus scaber meets the substance aspect of the Natural Health Product (NHP) definition, under item 1 (plant) of Schedule 1 to the NHP Regulations (Government of Canada 2010).

References:

Ahmad A., Alkarkhi A.F.M. 2009. Extraction, Separation and Identification of Chemical Ingredients of Elephantopus Scaber L. Using Factorial Design of Experiment. International Journal of Chemistry 1(1): 36-49.

But P.P.-H., Hon P.-H., Cao H., Chan T.W.D., Wu B.-W., Mak T.C.W., Che C.-T. 1997. Sesquiterpene lactones from Elephantopus scaber. Phytochemistry 44(1): 113-116.

Government of Canada 2010. Natural Health Products Regulations. URL:http://laws.justice.gc.ca/en/showtdm/cr/SOR-2003-196//?showtoc=&instrumentnumber=SOR-2003-196 [Accessed 2010-02-19].

USDA 2010. ARS, National Genetic Resources Program. Germplasm Resources Information Network - (GRIN) [Online Database]. National Germplasm Resources Laboratory, Beltsville, Maryland. URL: http://www.ars-grin.gov/cgi-bin/npgs/html/index.pl?language=en [Accessed 2010-02-19].";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:94:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1 item 1 (plant or plant material) of the NHP Regulations.";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:127:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 1 (plante ou matière végétale) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"85418";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:19:"Elephantopus scaber";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"AHN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:5:"PLANT";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";s:5:"title";s:23:"Elephantopus scaber_AHN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"197500";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:197501;a:25:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:11:"93789;94423";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:1496:"Proper name(s): Rheum pumilum (USDA 2010)
Common name(s): Xiao da huang (USDA 2010)

Rheum pumilum belongs to the Polygonaceae family (USDA 2010). Like with other members of the Rheum genus, qualitative analysis of this Rheum species has revealed the presence of anthraquinone derivatives, including emodin, physcion and chrysophanol (Peigen et al. 1984). Rheum pumilum is used in traditional Chinese medicine for its angiogenic effects, in combination with Panax ginseng and other traditional plants (Wu 2009).

Based on the above, Rheum pumilum meets the substance aspect of the Natural Health Product (NHP) definition, under item 1 (plant) of Schedule 1 to the NHP Regulations (Government of Canada 2010).

References:

Government of Canada 2010. Natural Health Products Regulations. URL: http://laws.justice.gc.ca/en/showtdm/cr/SOR-2003-196//?showtoc=&instrumentnumber=SOR-2003-196 [Accessed 2010-02-22].

Peigen X., Kiyi H., Liwei W. 1984. Ethnopharmacologic Study of Chinese Rhubarb. Journal of Ethnopharmacology 10: 275-293.

Wu Z.-g. 2009. Therapeutic Angiogenesis: The Combination Point of Chinese and Western Medicine in Prevention and Treatment of Ischemic Heart Disease. Chin. J. Integr. Med. 15(15): 323-324.";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:94:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1 item 1 (plant or plant material) of the NHP Regulations.";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:127:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 1 (plante ou matière végétale) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"85419";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:13:"Rheum pumilum";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"AHN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:5:"PLANT";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";s:5:"title";s:17:"Rheum pumilum_AHN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"197501";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:197502;a:25:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:11:"93793;94423";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:1709:"Proper name(s): Aconitum pendulum (USDA 2010)
Common name(s): Tei bang chui (USDA 2010)

Aconitum pendulum, a plant belonging to the Ranunculaceae family, is used in traditional Chinese medicine in anti-rheumatic and analgesic remedies (Xiao et al. 2006). It is also known to be used as a cardiotonic (Bisset 1981). Many Aconitum species, including Aconitum pendulum, are known to be toxic because of the presence of alkaloids such as benzoylmesaconine, mesaconitine, aconitine, and hypaconitine (Wang et al. 2006).

Based on the above, Aconitum pendulum meets the substance aspect of the Natural Health Product (NHP) definition, under item 1 (plant) of Schedule 1 to the NHP Regulations (Government of Canada 2010).

It contains flavonoids (such as kaempferol, myricetin, quercetin, and hyperoside), quinones (such as plumbagin, hydroplumbagin glucoside, and rossoliside), carotenoids, plant acids (such as butyric acid, citric acid, formic acid, gallic acid, malic acid, and propionic acid), resin, tannins (unspecified) and ascorbic acid (Barnes et al. 2007). Its extracts have value in respiratory disorders (Sweetman 2010).

Based on the above, Drosera rotundifolia meets the substance aspect of the Natural Health Product (NHP) definition, under Schedule 1, item 1 (plant) of the NHP Regulations (Government of Canada 2010).

URL: http://www.ars-grin.gov/cgi-bin/npgs/html/index.pl?language=en [Accessed 2010-02-16].";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:94:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1 item 1 (plant or plant material) of the NHP Regulations.";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:127:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 1 (plante ou matière végétale) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"85421";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:20:"Drosera rotundifolia";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"AHN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:5:"PLANT";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";s:5:"title";s:24:"Drosera rotundifolia_AHN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"197503";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:197504;a:25:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:11:"94086;94423";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:2056:"Radix Semiaquilegiae means roots of Semiaquilegia adoxoides (Niu et al. 2006), classified as follows:

Semiaquilegia adoxoides is a plant from the family Ranunculaceae, native to eastern Asia (GBIF 2010, IPNI 2010, NIH 2010, USDA 2010). The different parts and extracts of this plant have been used in traditional Chinese medicine, e.g. for its anti-inflammatory properties (Liu et al. 2005). Semiaquilegia adoxoides contains a variety of chemical constituents, such as cyano- and nitro-containing compounds (which are rare in plants), benzofuranone derivatives, diterpenoids, and many others (Niu et al. 2006).

Based on the above, Semiaquilegia adoxoides meets the substance aspect of the Natural Health Product (NHP) definition, under Schedule 1, item 1 (plant) of the NHP Regulations (Government of Canada 2010).

GBIF 2010. Global Biodiversity Information Facility. URL: http://data.gbif.org/welcome.htm [Accessed 2010-02-19].

URL: http://www.ars-grin.gov/cgi-bin/npgs/html/index.pl?language=en [Accessed 2010-02-19].";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:94:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1 item 1 (plant or plant material) of the NHP Regulations.";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:127:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 1 (plante ou matière végétale) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"85422";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:23:"Semiaquilegia adoxoides";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"AHN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:5:"PLANT";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";s:5:"title";s:27:"Semiaquilegia adoxoides_AHN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"197504";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:197505;a:25:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:11:"93792;94423";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:1580:"Proper name(s): Oxytropis falcata (Tropicos 2010)
Common name(s): Lian jia ji dou (Tropicos 2010)

Oxytropis falcata belongs to the Fabaceae family and is widely distributed in the west of China where it is the considered as "the king of herbal medicine" in Tibetan medicine because of its efficacy in treating ailments such as inflammation, pyreticosis and bleeding (Chen et al. 2009, Yang et al. 2009). It is also considered as a toxic plant, like many other Oxytropis species, causing severe poisoning to livestock after lenthy exposure (Chen et al. 2009, Chen et al. 2008).

Based on the above, Oxytropis falcata meets the substance aspect of the Natural Health Product (NHP) definition, under item 1 (plant) of Schedule 1 to the NHP Regulations (Government of Canada 2010).

Chromatographia 70(9/10): 1451-1454.";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:94:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1 item 1 (plant or plant material) of the NHP Regulations.";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:127:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 1 (plante ou matière végétale) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"85423";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:17:"Oxytropis falcata";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"AHN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:5:"PLANT";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";s:5:"title";s:21:"Oxytropis falcata_AHN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"197505";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:197506;a:25:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:11:"93829;94423";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:1745:"Proper names(s): Pinus palustris (USDA 2010)
Common names(s): Longleaf pine (USDA 2010)

Pinus palustris is a tree from the Pinaceae family that is native to the United States of America, mainly in the region of Virginia to East Texas (USDA 2010, Henderson and Grissino-Mayer 2009). It is one of the main sources of Turpentine, a Natural Health Product (NHP) which is derived from the oleoresin obtained from this plant and other species of the Pinus genus (Health Canada 2010, O'Neil et al. 2010).

Based on the above, Pinus palustris meets the substance aspect of the NHP definition, under item 1 (plant) of Schedule 1 to the NHP Regulations (Government of Canada 2010).

Common name: sago palm

Metroxylon sagu Rottb. is used as a staple food and a major source of carbohydrate in many parts of Asia though it is thought to have originated from New Guinea (Ehara 2000, USDA 2009). Its high starch content, high productivity and ease of cultivation in swampy regions have resulted in significant increases in the production of sago starch, and nowadays, it is commercially grown in plantations in countries like Indonesia and Malaysia (Kjaer 2004, Kuroda 2001).
Metroxylon sagu Rottb. will be considered as an NHP, under item 1 (Plant material) of Schedule 1 of the NHP regs.

It is believed that the antiurolithic property of the stem bark of this plant is due to the presence of lupeol (Khare 2007). It has also been used for its anti-inflammatory, astringent, laxative, and tonic activities; and this, in many therapeutic applications (Duke et al. 2002).

Based on the above, Crateva nurvala meets the substance aspect of the Natural Health Product (NHP) definition, under Schedule 1, item 1 (plant) of the NHP Regulations (Government of Canada 2010).

"Taxonomy for Plants- Germplasm Resources Information Network (GRIN)." from http://www.ars-grin.gov/cgi-bin/npgs/html/tax_search.pl.";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:94:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1 item 1 (plant or plant material) of the NHP Regulations.";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:127:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 1 (plante ou matière végétale) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"85430";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:21:"Clerodendrum chinense";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"AHN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:5:"PLANT";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";s:5:"title";s:25:"Clerodendrum chinense_AHN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"197512";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:197513;a:25:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:19:"94393;103355;103663";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:1954:"Proper name(s): Spirulina maxima (Guiry and Guiry 2010); changed to Arthrospira maxima (Guiry and Guiry 2013)
Common name(s): Spirulina (NMCD 2010)
Arthrospira maxima is a spiral-shaped blue-green alga that belongs to the Phormidiaceae family, known to live in warm climate countries, including alkaline lakes in Africa and Mexico (Guiry and Guiry 2010, Flores et al. 2003, Clément et al. 1967). It has been used both for its nutritional and therapeutic properties, as this alga is known to be rich in protein and other essential nutrients, including phenolic acids, tocopherols, and beta-carotene; and has shown to possess antioxidant properties (Flores et al. 2003, Miranda et al. 1998, Clément et al. 1967).
Based on the above, Arthrospira maxima meets the substance aspect of the Natural Health Product (NHP) definition, under item 1 (alga) of Schedule 1 to the NHP Regulations (Government of Canada 2010).

Chemical analysis on the extract of this plant revealed the presence of some alkaloids, saponins, flavonoids, anthraquinolines, and monoterpene glycosides (Anero et al. 2008, Yakubu et al. 2005).

Based on the above, Fadogia agrestis meets the substance aspect of the Natural Health Product (NHP) definition, under Schedule 1, item 1 (plant) of the NHP Regulations (Government of Canada 2010).

Common Name(s): Green ephedra (ITIS 2010, NIH 2010, USDA 2010a)

Ephedra viridis is a plant from the family Ephedraceae native to North America (ITIS 2010, NIH 2010, USDA 2010a, USDA 2010b). Many lignans were isolated from Ephedra viridis, some of them possessing antioxidant activity without cytotoxicity (Pullela et al. 2005). In many North American tribes, Ephedra viridis is used for urinary tract infections (Adams and Garcia 2006). Ephedra viridis contains pseudoephedrine, but not ephedrine (Adam and Garcia 2006, Moore 1999).

Based on the above, Ephedra viridis meets the substance aspect of the Natural Health Product (NHP) definition, under Schedule 1, item 1 (plant) of the NHP Regulations (Government of Canada 2010).

References:

Adams Jr. J.D., Cecilia Garcia C. 2006. Women's Health Among the Chumash. Evidence-Based Complementary and Alternative Medicine 3(1): 125–131.

Benzoic acid, silica, potassium hydroxide, aluminum oxide, iron oxide, and calcium have been reported as its major constituents, while antipyretic, hematuria, sedative, and antiemetic; among others, as its therapeutic values (Li 2009).

Based on the above, Phyllostachys nigra meets the substance aspect of the Natural Health Product (NHP) definition, under Schedule 1, item 1 (plant) of the NHP Regulations (Government of Canada 2010).

USDA 2010b. United States Department of Agriculture. Natural Resources Conservation Service. Plants Database. URL: http://plants.usda.gov/ [Accessed 2010-03-02].";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:94:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1 item 1 (plant or plant material) of the NHP Regulations.";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:127:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 1 (plante ou matière végétale) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"85434";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:19:"Phyllostachys nigra";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"AHN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:5:"PLANT";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";s:5:"title";s:23:"Phyllostachys nigra_AHN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"197516";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:197517;a:25:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:11:"94520;94423";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:1963:"Proper Name(s): Paris polyphylla (IPNI 2010, NIH 2010, USDA 2010)
Common Name(s): Himalayan paris (Li 2009)

Paris polyphylla is a plant from the family Melanthiaceae native to China, Nepal and India (IPNI 2010, NIH 2010, USDA 2010). It contains α-paristyphnin, diosgenin glycosides, furostanol, spirostanol, and saponins; constituents that have been associated with Paris polyphylla’s antioxidant, antispasmodic, anti-inflammatory, haemostatic, and anthelmintic properties (Li 2009, Gewali 2008, Khare 2007).

Based on the above, Paris polyphylla meets the substance aspect of the Natural Health Product (NHP) definition, under Schedule 1, item 1 (plant) of the NHP Regulations (Government of Canada 2010).

References:

Gewali M.B. 2008. Studies on the most traded medicinal plants from the Dolpa district of Nepal, Annual Report. Institute of Natural Medicine, University of Toyama.

USDA 2010. ARS, National Genetic Resources Program. Germplasm Resources Information Network - (GRIN) [Online Database]. National Germplasm Resources Laboratory, Beltsville, Maryland. URL: http://www.ars-grin.gov/cgi-bin/npgs/html/index.pl?language=en [Accessed 2010-03-19].";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:94:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1 item 1 (plant or plant material) of the NHP Regulations.";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:127:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 1 (plante ou matière végétale) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"85435";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:16:"Paris polyphylla";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"AHN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:5:"PLANT";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";s:5:"title";s:20:"Paris polyphylla_AHN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"197517";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:197518;a:25:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:11:"94521;94423";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:2028:"roper Name(s): Phyllophora crispa (GBIF 2010, Guiry and Guiry 2010, ITIS 2010, NIH 2010)
Common Name(s): Phyllophoran (SuriaLink 2010)

Phyllophora crispa is a marine red alga from the family Phyllophoraceae, mostly found in Northern Europe (Appeltans et al. 2010, GBIF 2010, Guiry and Guiry 2010, ITIS 2010, NIH 2010). It contains N-Acetyltyramine (Percot et al. 2009).

Based on the above, Phyllophora crispa meets the substance aspect of the Natural Health Product (NHP) definition, under Schedule 1, item 1 (alga) of the NHP Regulations (Government of Canada 2010).

References:

URL: http://www.seavegetables.com/HANDBOOK/INDEX.ASP [Accessed 2010-03-19].";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:75:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1 item 1 (alga) of the NHP Regulations.";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:103:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 1 (algue) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"85436";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:18:"Phyllophora crispa";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"AHN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:4:"ALGA";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";s:5:"title";s:22:"Phyllophora crispa_AHN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"197518";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:197519;a:25:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:11:"94565;94423";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:1648:"Proper Name(s): Litsea rotundifolia (GBIF 2010, USDA 2010)
Common Name(s): Round-leaved litsea (Hong Kong EPD 2010, Royal Forestry Society 1987)

Litsea rotundifolia is a plant from the family Lauraceae, native to China and Vietnam (GBIF 2010, USDA 2010). It contains aporphine alkaloids and is used in folk medicines for its analgesic and anti-inflammatory properties (Xiao et al. 2000).

Based on the above, Litsea rotundifolia meets the substance aspect of the Natural Health Product (NHP) definition, under Schedule 1, item 1 (plant) of the NHP Regulations (Government of Canada 2010).

GBIF 2010. Global Biodiversity Information Facility. URL: http://data.gbif.org/welcome.htm [Accessed 2010-03-25]

Journal of Tropical and Subtropical Plants 04.";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:94:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1 item 1 (plant or plant material) of the NHP Regulations.";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:127:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 1 (plante ou matière végétale) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"85437";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:19:"Litsea rotundifolia";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"AHN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:5:"PLANT";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";s:5:"title";s:23:"Litsea rotundifolia_AHN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"197519";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:197520;a:25:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:11:"94544;94423";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:1639:"Proper Name(s): Dipsacus asperoides, Dipsacus asper (USDA 2010)
Common Name(s): Sichuan teasel (USDA 2010)

Dipsacus asperoides is a plant from the family Dipsacaceae, native to China (USDA 2010). This plant, containing the alkaloid Lamine and essential oil, has been associated with the ability to increase leukocyte count and prevent spontaneous abortion (Li 2009). It has also been suggested that, due to its antioxidant constituents, Dipsacus asperoides might be beneficial to prevent the development and progression of atherosclerotic disease (Hung et al. 2006).

Based on the above, Dipsacus asperoides meets the substance aspect of the Natural Health Product (NHP) definition, under Schedule 1, item 1 (plant) of the NHP Regulations (Government of Canada 2010).

References:

Government of Canada 2010. Natural Health Products Regulations. URL: http://laws.justice.gc.ca/en/showtdm/cr/SOR-2003-196//?showtoc=&instrumentnumber=SOR-2003-196 [Accessed 2010-03-22].

URL: http://www.ars-grin.gov/cgi-bin/npgs/html/index.pl?language=en [Accessed 2010-03-22].";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:94:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1 item 1 (plant or plant material) of the NHP Regulations.";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:127:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 1 (plante ou matière végétale) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"85438";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:14:"Dipsacus asper";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"AHN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:5:"PLANT";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";s:5:"title";s:18:"Dipsacus asper_AHN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"197520";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:197521;a:25:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:11:"94836;94423";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:1705:"proper Name(s): Crataegus monogyna (ITIS 2010, USDA 2010a, USDA 2010b)
Common Name(s): Oneseed hawthorn (ITIS 2010, USDA 2010b)

Crataegus monogyna is a plant from the family Rosaceae, growing around the world (ITIS 2010, USDA 2010a, USDA 2010b). This plant contains many flavonoids and proanthocyanidins, used in herbal medicines for cardiovascular disorders (Sweetman 2010, Barnes et al. 2007, Fong and Bauman 2002).

Based on the above, Crataegus monogyna meets the substance aspect of the Natural Health Product (NHP) definition, under Schedule 1, item 1 (plant) of the NHP Regulations (Government of Canada 2010).

References:

Barnes J., Anderson L.A., Phillipson J.D. 2007. Herbal Medicines, Third Edition. Pharmaceutical Press, London, UK.

Fong H.H.S., Bauman J.L. 2002. Hawthorn. The Journal of Cardiovascular Nursing 16(4): 1-8.

USDA 2010b. United States Department of Agriculture. Natural Resources Conservation Service. Plants Database. URL: http://plants.usda.gov/ [Accessed 2010-04-06].";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:94:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1 item 1 (plant or plant material) of the NHP Regulations.";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:127:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 1 (plante ou matière végétale) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"85439";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:18:"Crataegus monogyna";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"AHN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:5:"PLANT";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";s:5:"title";s:22:"Crataegus monogyna_AHN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"197521";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:197522;a:25:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:11:"94806;94423";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:2308:"Proper Name(s): Lobaria pulmonaria, Sticta pulmonaria (GBIF 2010, USDA 2010)
Common Name(s): Lung lichen (USDA 2010), Lungmoss (Duke et al. 2002, Fleming et al. 2000)

Sticta pulmonaria, a synonym for Lobaria pulmonaria, is a lichen from the family Lobariaceae, mostly found in North America and Northern Europe (GBIF 2010, USDA 2010). It contains lichen acids such as gyrophoric acid, stictic acid, norstictic acid, and telophoric acid, as well as ergosterol, episterol, fecosterol and lichesterol (Süleyman et al. 2003, Safe et al. 1976). Lobaria pulmonaria has diaphoretic, expectorant, anti-inflammatory, and antimicrobial effects (Duke et al. 2002, Fleming et al. 2000).

Based on the above, Lobaria pulmonaria meets the substance aspect of the Natural Health Product (NHP) definition, under Schedule 1, item 1 (Fungus) of the NHP Regulations (Government of Canada 2010).

URL: http://plants.usda.gov/ [Accessed 2010-04-07].";s:29:"field_quantity_restriction_on";s:0:"";s:17:"field_rationale_e";s:77:"Classified as an NHP under Schedule 1 item 1 (fungus) of the NHP Regulations.";s:17:"field_rationale_f";s:108:"Classifié comme PSN sous Annexe 1, article 1 (champignon) du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_e";s:0:"";s:24:"field_restriction_desc_f";s:0:"";s:17:"field_upper_limit";s:0:"";s:10:"field_date";s:0:"";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"85440";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:17:"Sticta pulmonaria";s:20:"field_ingredient_cat";s:3:"AHN";s:25:"field_nhpd_classification";s:4:"FUNG";s:10:"field_unit";s:0:"";s:20:"field_limitation_ref";s:0:"";s:9:"field_ref";s:4:"NHPD";s:15:"field_other_ref";s:0:"";s:5:"title";s:21:"Sticta pulmonaria_AHN";s:3:"nid";s:6:"197522";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:197523;a:25:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"MI";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:5:"94724";s:17:"field_lower_limit";s:0:"";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:2223:"Proper Name(s): Pseudotsuga menziesii (NIH 2010, USDA 2010a, USDA 2010b)
Common Name(s): Douglas-fir (NIH 2010, USDA 2010a, USDA 2010b)

Pseudotsuga menziesii is a plant from the family Pinaceae, native to North America but later introduced in Europe (NIH 2010, USDA 2010a, USDA 2010b). The chemical constituents of this plant include, but is not limited to, α- and β-pinene, sabinene, (Z and E)-β-ocimene, α-terpinolene, α-terpineol, citronellyl acetate, α- and γ-terpinene, limonene, 3-carene, myrcene, 2-hexenal, ethyl caproate, citronellal, and α-phellandrene; used for its antiseptic, antimicrobial, antitussive, vermicide, laxative, and diuretic properties (Duke et al. 2002, Tesevic et al. 2009).

Based on the above, Pseudotsuga menziesii meets the substance aspect of the Natural Health Product (NHP) definition, under Schedule 1, item 1 (plant) of the NHP Regulations (Government of Canada 2010).
